Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Education
Sub-Output: Ukraine Teacher Professional Development. Digital pedagogy with elements of SEL and MHPSS
Description: To support the continuity of education in Ukraine, UNESCO, Google, and the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine provide 50,000 Chromebooks for teachers. To complement the use of those devices and contributing to the digital transformation of the education system in Ukraine, UNESCO is providing teachers with a suite of resources and an online course to develop their skills in digital pedagogies.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Private company
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.,5.b Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
Geography: Rivnenska, Mykolaivska, Ivano-Frankivska, Ternopilska, Zhytomyrska, Volynska, Donetska, Vinnytska, Dnipropetrovska, Zaporizka, Kyivska, Poltavska, Kharkivska, Sumska, Odeska, Khmelnytska, Khersonska, Chernivetska, Cherkaska, Kyiv city, Chernihivska, Ukraine, Zakarpatska, Kirovohradska, Lvivska
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output’s contribution to gender equality is limited compared to its overall outcomes, at the same time it enables these contributions to be tracked and reported through the inclusion of indicators that capture gender-related data, disaggregation  and further analysis.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The project document identifies one element of the human rights marker, which corresponds to the sub-result making a limited contribution to the realization of human rights.
2022 Narrative: Administrative start of the project. Data is collected on teachers' needs for digital, SEL and MHPSS skills. Building relationships with local teachers' institutions.Funding was received by the end of 2022.
2023 Narrative: Launched in October 2023, UNESCO’s “Digital Teacher” training in Ukraine has already attracted more than 48,000 teachers. Through this online course, Ukrainian teachers are developing pedagogical skills in the use of digital tools for the delivery of quality distance education. An an online Community of Practice was also created for peer learning among teachers, which has been joined by more than 12,000 teachers.
2024 Narrative: 49,985 Chromebooks were delivered to Ukrainian teachers with the support of Google, enabling them to continue the educational process and conduct online lessons. In addition, in support of the digital transformation of the country's education system and the urgent need for MHPSS in education, over 65,000 teachers received training on digital pedagogical skills and MHPSS with acertification rate of 40%. And also over 209,000 teachers have completed Google's Digital Tools for Education program.

Six interoperable electronic services of the highest level of sophistication were developed, while other five will be considered as a priority in next implementation phase. Project identified and proposed how the current digital governance eco-system can be used, upgraded, and improved to respond to Montenegrin context and digital maturity, with fully described technical specifications for the development and upgrade of aforementioned systems. Project supported establishment of network of ICT practitioners, in order to ensure capacity building in public administration when it comes to the digital governance acceleration. In addition, project supports initiatives in cybersecurity, especially development of Government CIRT portal and strenghtening capacities in this field.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from strengthened human capital including early childhood development, and more resilient, gender-responsive, and quality healthcare and education
Output: 3.2. Quality education
Sub-Output: Enhance  primary and secondary teachers' digital and media and information literacy skills for quality delivery of digital learning and prevention of cyber-bullying
Description: Training will be organized for primary and secondary school teachers to equip them with skills on the use of MS tools for online/offline and blended learning delivery.  Teachers’s capacity-building will be implemented through training workshops which will focus on the use of MIL to tackle disinformation and how to integrate and increase civil engagement knowledge in the classroom. Online courses will be developed to strengthen teachers's capacities for prevention and tackling of violence in online environment.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The programme supports women and girls’ empowerment, participation and leadership. Key activities are focused on long-term investments in empowering teaching workforce that promotes gender equality as well as encouraging girls, particularly from the most disadvantaged communities to benefit from educational and career prospects in ICT and tech-related sectors. Throughout all programme activities, equitable access to quality and inclusive education systems and learning outcomes will be strongly emphasized to lead to the implementation of the SDGs 5 on Gender Equality.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: In terms of Human Rights Based approach, the focus of the initiative is not only to enable children to have access to school, but in the long-term to provide opportunities to have a quality curriculum and complete all years of schooling to fulfil their right to education. Crucial are teachers, school management and other staff, playing key roles in creating safe learning spaces, adapting curricula and providing support to marginalized students.   Education authorities in Montenegro are faced with a unique set of challenges in ensuring the continuity and quality of learning with ‘Leave no one behind’ principle3. This Joint programme proposes to modernise education and learning in Montenegro, as well as to contribute to the education sector reforms with the ultimate goal of ensuring equal, quality and relevant education for all children and youth. The joint programme will particularly address the needs of the most marginalized learners (such as children and youth from remote and rural areas, socio-economically disadvantaged families and Roma/Egyptian communities).
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: During the inception phase, consultations with the MICROSOFT as the implementing partner will be initiated in order to ensure provision of capacity building programs in line with specific needs of teachers and strategic objectives of the Ministry of Education.
2024 Narrative: UNESCO, in partnership with the Ministry of Education, Science and Innovation, Media Institute in Montenegro and NGO "Unionica u pokretu" launched the implementation of 2 capacity-building programmes for primary and secondary teachers, in media and information literacy and use of Office 365, respectively. The training programmes are implemented in 12 primary and secondary schools in 6 municipalities in the Northern Montenegro region. So far, 142 primary and secondary teachers have received training on media and information literacy, with the objective of systemic cross-curricular integration of media and information literacy among primary and secondary school students. The office 365 training is ongoing, targeting at least 300 teachers. Further, UNESCO supports the developement of several online self-paced courses, to be integrated into the Digital School learning platform, focused on the use of Office 365 tools, as well as prevention of online violence.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from strengthened human capital including early childhood development, and more resilient, gender-responsive, and quality healthcare and education
Output: 3.2. Quality education
Sub-Output: Enhancing digital transformation of education with particular focus on vulnerable groups in line with Strategy for Digitalization of Education (2022 - 2027)(MAF)
Description:
The sub-output funded under MAF will focus on the following interventions:
·	Capacity building of teachers on modern didactics for online, offline, and blended learning, including a learner-centred approach, e-pedagogy and special support for the most vulnerable students. 
·	Development and adaptation of content for the Digital School Platform, for students and teachers – with a focus on quality and inclusive digital content for STEM skills, career guidance (based on the Prilike Programme), core-employability skills and prevention of online violence. 
·	Establishing EdTech hubs at schools (primarily schools in the northern parts with large numbers of Roma and disabled students) by fostering focal points for digitalisation among teachers, supporting networks and partnerships between schools.
·	Organizing Digital Skills Summer Camps for disadvantaged adolescents in underserved communities in the north of the country
Implementation partners: Elementary schools, Secondary schools
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output significantly contributes to gender equality and empowerment. This encompasses encouraging at least equal, if not even higher participation of women and girls in all activities, as well as analysing gender-equity with a situation-based approach, strategically considering the gender dynamics among different groups (e.g., among teachers, students, Roma and Egyptian students, etc.). Key project activities focus on the long-term empowerment of the female teaching workforce, promoting gender equality and encouraging girls, particularly the most disadvantaged, to seize educational and career opportunities in STEM and tech-related sectors.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: In terms of a Human Rights Based approach, the sub-output seeks to enable all children and adolescents, in particular those from disadvantaged groups, to have equitable access to school, to benefit from a quality education and to complete all years of schooling, in line with their right to education. This complies with the Montenegrin Constitution, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and other relevant international human rights instruments. The joint project outputs will make the education system more resilient, adaptable to student needs, equitable, and inclusive, while harnessing the potential of technology and teachers' capacity in a meaningful way.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: Main interventions within this output refer to Capacity building of teachers, practitioners and school staff as well as support to infrastructure development, as well as digital skills development of children, adolescents and young people.  Country wide training for ICT coordinators to implement Digitalna škola concept and enhance its use in classroom for the benefit of children, adolescents and teachers is envisaged for at least 170 ICT coordinators, being implemented until Dec 2024 and is on track.Furthermore, capacity-building for primary and secondary teachers is in progress, as envisaged from Q4 2024 until Q2 2025, where at least 300 teachers will be capacitated to implement STEM/coding courses as regular and extra-curricular programs in the area of 3D modelling and printing, programming, coding, PET recycling and robotics.Over 6000 children and adolescents in communities across north, facing different deprivations, particularly in relation to access to digital skills development will be supported to take part in the programme developed and established within EdTech hubs and with active support from, abovementioned, capacitated teachers.Furthermore, UNICEF supported the Ministry to establish the EdTech hubs and related programme across twelve primary and secondary schools in the north of the country, reaching 6,000 students. Over 500 children were supported to develop digital, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills in 12 primary schools, as well as an additional 1,120 through UNICEF supported workshops at the national Days of Science Festival.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP3_Enhanced shared prosperity in a sustainable economy
Outcome: OC3_By 2027, all people of Moldova, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, competitive and sustainable economic development and equal access to decent work and productive employment
Output: OU 3.1_Policy and institutional frameworks create an empowering environment for inclusive and sustainable economic development that promotes creation of productive and decent work
Sub-Output: Strengthening institutional frameworks and capacities of cultural and creative sectors through the use of technology especially the development of digital skills in order to create the sectors' economic stability (UNESCO)
Description: As culture generates an important part of national production, and income and sustains the livelihoods of its citizens, this project wants to highlight the importance of creating new digital cultural spaces to access and consume cultural and creative sectors through technology. It focuses on identifying new opportunities for cultural and creative production, dissemination, and consumption of cultural goods and services.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: Government of the Republic of Korea
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Culture
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,11.3 By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
QCPR function: Normative Support, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: gender equality was mainstreamed throughout the project implementation, while the project also integrated gender-specific and gender transformative outcomes in the results framework.  For example, the Activity 1 foresaw the development of the Online registry for the CCIs where collection of sex-disaggregated data was envisaged in order to track gender equality in the cultural sector. In the same way, Activity 3 ensured to include the representatives of the diverse communities in the trainings, not to mention the balanced representation of male and female participants, as well as youth (students).
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The principle of gender equality and human rights-based approach is mainstreamed in the UNESCO-KFIT programme, and the programme is in line with UNESCO Gender Equality Action Plan in the context that the COVID-19 pandemic have taken a disproportionate toll on female artists and cultural professionals, even though Cultural and Creative Industries (CCIs) are among the sectors with the highest employment rate of women.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: Mapping the cultural and creative industries in order to establish an online registry A multi-stakeholder national online register of the cultural and creative sectors has been established combining government institutions, the private sector, civil society organisations, and individual entrepreneurs with an aim to inform decision makers about the current status and potential of the creative economy in the country. The register will be used to showcase the added value of CCIs in the economy, especially the fact that these industries are the main employer of highly skilled workers, especially young people. Assessing the digital skills and competencies of creative professionals and artistsThe report provides an overview of key trends, opportunities, challenges, and major projects related to digital creative skills in Moldova, followed by a series of recommendations in areas such as the development of new digital skills courses, the promotion of international mobility and networking, the updating of curricula in universities and schools, the implementation of monitoring and awareness-raising activities, and the introduction of new public sector policiesTrainings programs to strengthen the digital skills and competencies of creative professionals and artistsTailor-made courses for universities were developed on specific digital skill sets for the creation, dissemination, and marketing of cultural goods and services (Activity 3). The aim is to support culture and creative professionals in improving their digital competences, so as to become more productive in the new digital era, efficient in collaborating with other professionals and organisations inside and outside of their sector, and successful in managing emerging challenges. The aim of this activity is also to enable students to develop their digital skills for successful employment and progress in the modern workplace. A new program named “P2P Experience” related to Graphic design and Animation for university teachers has been created by ArtCor in cooperation with the Academy of Music, Theatre and Fine Arts. It is designed to guide teachers in development of technical and theoretical skills necessary for teaching in the newly created speciality: Graphic design and Animation, covering design fundaments, technical skills in graphic design, and the basics of animation.

Description: The proposed project seeks to strengthen the tourism, cultural and creative economy sectors by introducing digital technologies and spurring innovation to boost competitiveness, production of higher-added-value products, employment and sustainable economic growth. In particular, drawing upon Slovenian expertise and experience, the project will facilitate the adoption of digital technologies with a view of managing tourist flows and supporting SMEs active in the tourism sector and creative economy to adjust and improve their products/services according to visitors’ expectations, thereby contributing to improved economic performance and well-being of local communities.
Implementation partners: Ministry of Science and Technological Development Montenegro, University of Donja Gorica

SDG Goals: 7 Affordable and Clean Energy, 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Montenegro is dedicated to upholding the principles of gender equality and eradicating violence against women and girls across all aspects of society. To achieve this, the country has established a comprehensive National Plan for Advancing Gender Equality, rooted in the Beijing Platform for Action. Montenegro is unwavering in its commitment to execute this plan effectively and to further enhance its domestic legislation on gender equality, thus guaranteeing women's complete involvement in decision-making processes. Moreover, Montenegro is actively engaged in ongoing efforts to raise awareness and conduct educational campaigns aimed at ending violence against women, which includes the active participation of men and boys. At the inception of the project, a gender analysis of the situation in the country will be conducted. The project aims at encouraging women and youth to participate in the project activities, and to ensure that women and men, as well as persons with disabilities, equally benefit from capacity building and other activities wherever possible. The project will also benefit from the equal participation of women and men in both project management and as beneficiaries, partners and key stakeholders of the project. The project management team will also strive to encourage gender parity in planning the project activities and will ensure that recommendations and policy reviews prepared during the project implementation will be gender-responsive, and liaison with sector-specific women’s business associations and civil society groups working on the intersection of gender, digital transformation and AI will be established. In compliance with the UNIDO Gender Mainstreaming Guidelines, project personnel will take the basic “I Know Gender” online course in the UN Women e-Learning Campus (https://trainingcentre.unwomen.org) for learning and promoting relevant issues. Further, all advocacy materials and other communication activities will use gender-inclusive language and gender-balanced representation as well as not use images/descriptions that would reinforce gender stereotypes. The Gender digital divide is considered for project activities. Specific challenges for women to access and adopt frontier technologies will be addressed and raised whenever possible. It should be noted that statistics for university graduates show that women are better educated in Montenegro than men. However, employment statistics show much lower figures in active employment7. Against this background, the project will ensure that female participation is actively promoted, particularly when it comes to identifying pilot companies to use the technologies for digitalizing cultural heritage Providing innovative, cutting-edge technologies specifically to female entrepreneurs could have a positive reinforcement effect, so any criteria for selection will specifically consider companies with higher percentages of female employment, and encourage others to target women in their activities for cultural heritage. Further the project will collect sex-disaggregated data, whenever feasible, and advocate the inclusion of women-run/-owned enterprises for pilot activities when companies are involved. A preliminary target is set of at least 30% of women-owned and women-led firms to be involved as project beneficiaries, which can be considered a gender-transformative measure given the low ratio of women entrepreneurs in this field as reported in 2021, 31.34 % of entrepreneurs in Montenegro are women. The project will consider setting target for women’s participation in capacity-building activities of at least 40%. These targets will be adapted following the receipt of results of the study under Output 1 and Output 2.
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace

2024 Narrative: The receipt of funding from the donor was delayed. The project will be launched at the beginning of 2025.

2022 Narrative: A total of 10 new e-services were launched with UNDP support in 2022 to address the needs of Ukrainians representing, among others, vulnerable groups, e.g., IDPs and elderly people. Among others, these include registration of IDP status (online and via service centres), obtaining an insurance certificate, digital pension certificate in Diia mobile app, as well as two additional services related to child adoption. Up to 31 December 2022, over 9 million applications were submitted for newly established services developed in line with WCAG recommendations on web accessibility. Moreover, over 90% of surveyed applicants were satisfied with the functionality of the online services. This demonstrates that regardless of the war-related difficulties, the public services introduced with UNDP support remain effective and accessible to the Ukrainian people
2023 Narrative: UNDP contributed to improving of quality access to digital administrative and social services by launching 19 e-services and digital tools tailored to address the needs of Ukrainians, representing among others vulnerable groups, e.g., older people and war veterans. These include monetary support of war-disabled war veterans, monetization of children's sanitation, allocation and processing of child benefits to single parent, as well as 6 services on child adoption. By 30 December 2023, the new services received an overwhelming response, with a total of over 10 million applications submitted, with equal access for women and men. In order to facilitate the fulfilment of the new National Standard on web accessibility, UNDP supported the development of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine Resolution #757 adopted on 21 July 2023 that makes the DSTU obligatory for all state-funded web- and mobile-based informational resources. To empower women working or willing to work in the field of digitalisation policy design and the reengineering of public services, 18 mid-level women specialists have strengthened their knowledge of the digital transformation process and professional networks by participating in the Leadership Programme for Women Innovators organized by UNDP.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Democratic Governance
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - Democratic Governance
Output: Output 1.1.2 - Enhanced capacity of the public administration, law enforcement and independent institutions to ensure security and deliver inclusive, people-centered services.
Sub-Output: 1.1.2.48 - Digital governance acceleration
Description:
The overall objective is to improve the institutional resilience and enhancing the trust in institutions through support to digital governance transformation. The goal of the project is to support the transition towards an adaptive, effective and open governance to place human development at the center of digital transformation.
The project envisages the following three outputs:
Output 1: Improved Institutional and policy framework for digital governance to enable inclusive digital transformation;
Output 2: Enhanced collaboration with citizens and private sector in digitalization of public services that maximize the human development outcomes;
Output 3: Institutions equipped and supported to design effective digital governance policy and deliver quality services for all citizens.
This intervention will help the government to:
-	change the way they work and organize themselves in order to anticipate and rapidly respond to the needs of their citizens and businesses, and
-	ensure they have the skill sets needed to work collaboratively and engage with citizens and businesses.
Implementation partners: Ministry of Economic Development and Tourism Montenegro, Ministry of Finance Montenegro, Montenegro Ministry of Public Administration Montenegro
SDG Targets: 16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Pillar 1 Sustainable economic growth, environment and employment.
Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - By 2022, all women and men, especially young people, equally benefit from an enabling environment that includes labour market, access to decent jobs and economic opportunities
Output: Output 1.1.3 - Government and other stakeholder are equipped with knowledge and skills for gender responsive policies on investment, trade and employment.
Sub-Output: Supporting Ukraine’s women-driven MSMEs in the agri-food and adjacent sectors, in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, to boost their resilience to similar shocks and support a rebound, following business models reengineering, access to on-demand extension services and provision of guided digital transformation support
Implementation partners: Business Association, Micro, Small and Medium-sized Enterprise
SDG Targets: 8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
2021 Narrative: A total of 32 agriculture MSMEs, including 17 women-led enterprises, have already joined the export-oriented umbrella brand that was developed 'from scratch' with UNDP support (included development of the umbrella brand concept, brand guidelines for the Organic Ukraine Business Hub and identification of priority product categories for export through a participatory process). The MSMEs are expected to receive significant benefits from exporting under umbrella, such as higher product quality, reduced risks and barriers, and synergistic savings in advertising, logistics, transportation and other operating costs. The umbrella brand is being administered by partner BMO “Organic Ukraine” given the production capacity and interest of its member MSMEs, availability of women-led enterprises among them, priorities for export markets and expectations from export as well as BMO’s commitment to be engaged in the initiative. The initiative was implemented in cooperation with the Ministry of Digital Transformation of Ukraine, Entrepreneurship and Export Promotion Office and Diia.Business.

Strategic priority: Effective governance and justice for all
Outcome: Outcome 1. By 2025 all people and groups in Uzbekistan, especially the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from enhanced accountable, transparent, inclusive and gender responsive governance systems and rule of law institutions for a life free from discrimination and violence
Output: Output 1.1. National institutions have strengthened capacities to apply effective anti-corruption, accountability and transparency tools, digital innovations and mechanisms for delivering better gender-responsive and disability-sensitive public services to all, with a focus on the most vulnerable
Sub-Output: Capacities of government to conduct digital economic diplomacy are improved
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Ministry of Foreign Affairs
SDG Targets: 17.3 Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.,17.6 Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.,17.8 Fully operationalize the technology bank and science, technology and innovation capacity-building mechanism for least developed countries by 2017 and enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In progress. In 2021, UNDP supported the MFA in drafting a Concept on Economic Diplomacy, which defines principles, strategic objectives, priorities and implementation mechanisms for promoting economic diplomacy of Uzbekistan. Draft Presidential Decree “On measures to improve the efficiency of economic diplomacy and the accelerated development of digital diplomacy” and detailed Program of priority measures for the development of economic and digital diplomacy for 2021-2022 have been developed.
An intensive training workshop on “Economic and Digital Diplomacy” was conducted on 3-4 December 2021, for over 70 participants (10% are women) from 16 government bodies, overseas diplomatic missions, associations and NGOs.
An information system designed and launched in November 2021 to streamline the daily flow of data and information from overseas missions to MFA with respect to activities on attraction of investment, export promotion, contract enforcement. The system aims at improving internal business processes and better data management for more effective promotion of economic diplomacy objectives.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, UNDP supported the MFA in establishing a Studio of Economic and Digital Diplomacy for information, analytical and digital support to the Ministry in economic diplomacy. The studio has produced an investment guidebook "New Uzbekistan: Seizing Opportunities" (presented in Sep 2022), and disseminates a monthly e-digest of reforms and developments in Uzbekistan for international partners.30 diplomats were trained in such areas as export and trade promotion, digital and networked diplomacy, investment projects management, English for professionals, and other topics through 1 workshops, 6 study trips, and 1 language course.UNDP also enhanced the MFA’s digital capacity through developing a web portal "Economic Diplomacy" to support Uzbek exporters and attract investments to Uzbekistan.

Contributing partners: Core Funding, Global Agriculture and Food Security Program Fund, World Food Programme Multilateral Fund
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Labour, Social Security and Migration
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,1.b Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,5.c Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.,10.4 Adopt policies, especially fiscal, wage and social protection policies, and progressively achieve greater equality.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.,17.14 Enhance policy coherence for sustainable development.

Gender marker narrative: National data exchange systems stregthening was based on gender-disaggregated data and integration to the extent possible.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: In the course of strengthening and digitizing national social protection information system and data exchange, number of activities were implemented, including the internal planning for monitoring and targeting practices for the nationwide scale up of the Governments “Social Contract” project, which was initially piloted in 2022. Additionally, TORs for trainers to conduct capacity strengthening activities for the Ministry of Labour, Social Security and Migration staff, who execute administrative procedures for the “Social Contract” project, as well as the participants in spheres of digital skills, agriculture, digital banking were developed. Regional mission was organized to assess social protection information system and social protection areas. Furthermore, work specifically designed to enhance digitalization of social passport, a Government system registering vulnerable citizens, was initiated and is subject for further implementation in 2024.
2024 Narrative: WFP continued to support the Government in establishing an inclusive social protection system, which can potentially play a crucial role in mitigating the negative effects of economic and climate shocks. The overall goal is to align the system with international standards and address the gaps identified in the social protection assessment conducted in 2022 using the Core Diagnostic Instrument (CODI). In 2024, strategic outcome 1 supported the Ministry of Labour, Social Security, and Migration in developing an analysis-based plan to enhance the 'Social Passport of a Low-income Family', the Ministry’s digital registry of poor families. The upgraded registry aims to track the distribution of humanitarian aid during emergencies, improving the social protection system's ability to target the most vulnerable people of all age groups during disasters and other shocks.

Plan name: Turkmenistan UNSDCF 2021 - 2025
Strategic priority: Priority A: People centred governance and rule of law
Outcome: Outcome 1 By 2025, people have access to more effective, innovative, and transparent public administration based upon the rule of law, human rights, gender equality, labour rights, and quality data
Output: Output 1.1. The state institutions of Turkmenistan equipped with knowledge, skills and tools to introduce the systems of digital government, document management, and provision of efficient services to the population using ‘one stop shop’ principles
Sub-Output: Promoting the development of digital public services in Turkmenistan
Description: Developing of piloting digital system-Unified Register of Civil Registry Office (ZAGS)
Implementation partners: Turkmenistan Ministry of Adalat (Justice)
SDG Targets: 17.7 Promote the development, transfer, dissemination and diffusion of environmentally sound technologies to developing countries on favourable terms, including on concessional and preferential terms, as mutually agreed.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: UNDP CO has continued its efforts on building digital capacities of public institutions via the introduction of digital public services. The CO has developed and piloted the Digital Civil Registry with the Ministry of Adalat (Justice) through digitalization of registration processes for seven types of acts of civil status, delivering and installing the server equipment, providing in-depth training for IT personnel of national partners, and scanning and digitizing historical records of acts of civil status. The piloting of digital registration was done during two months and more than 5.5K records were processed in a new platform. Moreover, more than 3K historical records were scanned and digitized in pdf format. The server equipment was procured and installed at the Ministry sites. In addition, using RFF opportunity the CO has established effective partnership with the Agency "Turkmenaragatnashyk" and MoU has been signed to introduce electronic data interchange (EDI) system. The CO has also conducted series of consultations on the development of electronic data interchange system. As a result a Roadmap has been developed for the implementation of the EDI system in Turkmenistan. The EDI system is an important stage in the process of digitalization of public services for people and businesses in the country. EDI helps to simplify procedures while facilitating the exchange of business documents and data across a variety of platforms and programs. Moreover, the CO has continued supporting the Civil Service Academy on building digital capacities of civil servants by: - developing a pilot desktop application for testing civil servants on digital economy and management; - developing a new course "Digital economy" to provide knowledge and competencies for mid-level civil servants to act as future digital transformation leaders; - establishing a new Digital Economy Certification Center; - implementing a new mechanism of civil servants' education using distance learning technologies.
2023 Narrative: Operational closure of the project in 2023Summary of main/key achievements of the project:·        the first UNDP Turkmenistan-funded hackathon conducted for young software developers ·        First UNDP Turkmenistan in-house software development piloted·        server hardware equipment procured and installed·        3-month intensive Network Administrator technical training conducted for national partners' IT team ·        planetary scanner for scanning civil registration historical records procured and installed·        A series of seminars and consultations held on the digitalization of public services and preparations for the launch of a project to develop an EDI (Electronical Data Interchange) G2G data exchange system

Plan name: Turkmenistan UNSDCF 2021 - 2025
Strategic priority: Priority A: People centred governance and rule of law

Sub-Output: More effective and efficient WHO providing better support to countries: Strengthened country capacity in data and innovation. Support to the implementation of the national HIS and digitalization strategy and action plan
Description:
More effective and efficient WHO providing better support to countries: Strengthened country capacity in data and innovation. Support to the implementation of the national HIS and digitalization strategy and action plan.
Activities for 2022-23:
* Support to the implementation of the national HIS and digitalization strategy and action plan.
* Support to the introduction and transition to ICD 11
* Maintain reporting on SDG indicators and the EPW measurement framework
Activities for 2024-25:
* Support in the implementation of the national HIS strategy and action plan for 2019–2025 and in the development and implementation of a new strategy for health digitalization
* Support in the implementation of and transition to ICD 11
* Increasing the capacity of HIS and DH specialists in the field of public health protection and in the development of a regulatory framework for HIS and DH
Implementation partners: Turkmenistan Ministry of Health and Medical Industry
SDG Targets: 3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2024 Narrative: 1.     Health Data Standardization: A comprehensive mapping analysis of 621 health data entry and reporting forms was completed with WHO support. Two working groups of Ministry of Health (MoH) Turkmenistan specialists utilized a WHO digital tool for this survey. WHO experts from the Moscow Digital Health Collaborating Centre analyzed the collected data and provided recommendations to the MoH for data standardization and dataset design, laying the foundation for a future digital health information system.2.     Capacity Building: Several training activities enhanced the skills of Turkmen specialists:·        Three MoH specialists participated in a training program in Berlin, Germany (July 8-12, 2024), focused on supporting the digitalization of health information systems in Central Asian Republics. This training addressed critical areas for successful digital HIS transformation.·        Two MoH IT specialists received training on Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) standards in Tashkent, Uzbekistan (September 23-27, 2024), conducted by WHO.·        One Health Statistics specialist from the MoH and one specialist from the Turkmenistan State Statistics Committee attended a WHO training on ICD-11 in Almaty, Kazakhstan (December 9-13, 2024).3.     Networking and Knowledge Exchange: Turkmenistan actively participated in various networking and knowledge-sharing initiatives:·        A member of the Health Information Network attended the Inaugural Meeting of the WHO/Europe Strategic Partners’ Initiative for Data and Digital Health and the Second meeting of the WHO European Region Health Information Network (HIN) in Copenhagen, Denmark (June 13-14, 2024).·        WHO experts from Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan shared their countries' digital health development experiences at the MoH's annual International Scientific Conference on Health (October 10-12, 2024).·        Turkmenistan contributed to and was featured in the Regional Survey on Digital Health Leveraging and Expanding Digital Transformation to Improve Health in the European Region, the results of which were published in the WHO publication "Digital health country profiles: Exploring the digital health landscape in the WHO European Region" (April 2024).·        MoH specialists participated in WHO online events, including the first virtual meeting of the WHO Health Information Network (February 28, 2024) and a session on Enhancing Cybersecurity in Health (July 18, 2024).

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.1: By 2025, effective, inclusive and accountable institutions ensure equal access for all people living in Kazakhstan, especially most vulnerable, to quality and gender sensitive social services according to the principle of leaving no one behind
Output: Output 1.1.2: Increased capacity of policy makers and health service providers to improve access to selected quality health services and goods, including those related to COVID-19, HIV, reproductive and mental health related services, for everyone especially the most vulnerable groups of population.
Sub-Output: Enhance capacities of CSOs working with MSM to develop innovative and customized digital solutions to reach out to key populations (MSM and transgender persons) and their partners across the country (via dating apps, quiz-bots, messengers, other targeted media) to empower them for testing and those with known HIV+ status to initiate treatment.
Description: 2021: A media campaign is being prepared to empower people living with HIV (adults and young people/adolescents) to adhere to HIV treatment and reduce HIV-related stigma and discrimination including self-stigma. For this, a media company called “7 Media” was selected through a competitive bidding. It first reviewed similar campaigns previously implemented in Kazakhstan and other countries and suggested to move away from traditional short videos demonstrated on TV and in digital media. Instead of one or several public service announcements, 7 Media developed a script for a single 20-minute feature film having consultations with people living with HIV, health professionals, opinion leaders and celebrities. By the end of 2021, the film was shot. After post-production refinements, soundtrack recording, poster and teaser production, the film will be released and heavily promoted on popular websites and communities in social media networks. The tentative launch date of the film is 14 February 2022 and it's expected to reach at least 100,000 views by 31 March 2022.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: UNAIDS Unified Budget, Results and Accountability Framework
Implementation partners: Kaz Soiuz NGO, Kazakhstan Centre for Dermatology and Infectious Diseases, World Health Organization
SDG Targets: 3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.,4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,16.1 Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
QCPR function: Support Functions, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance

2021: A media campaign is being prepared to empower people living with HIV (adults and young people/adolescents) to adhere to HIV treatment and reduce HIV-related stigma and discrimination including self-stigma. During the reporting period, UNESCO has selected a partner organization in order to build information, communication and educational work in Russian and Kazakh languages ​​to raise awareness of the population about HIV and STIs, safer behavior, prevention, testing (including self-testing) and HIV treatment, as well as resources and organizations to go to for help. At the same time, it is planned to pay special attention to working with communities of young MSM and transgender people. By the end of this year, it's planned to conduct  research to identify promising areas for interaction with the target audience in the creation of educational content, as well as its knowledge, needs and information needs. And based on the identified needs, a series of materials (content units) in various formats in Russian and Kazakh languages will be developed and promoted on the Internet and social networks in order to reach the widest possible coverage of target audience.
In Q3, UNESCO with the selected partner - NGO "Public Fund Center for Scientific and Practical Initiatives" is working on the methodology and objectives of the research on the topics of HIV awareness, relevance and resources of information about HIV and STIs, attitudes towards people with HIV, as well as media consumption among various target audiences, especially MSM and transgender people. After the research, needs-based content and resources will be developed and promoted.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.5_State institutions and CSOs ensure effective prevention and improved multisectoral response to address all forms of violence against women and girls, including harmful practices and discriminatory gender norms and stereotypes
Sub-Output: (UNFPA)  Supporting MLSP with the provision of GBV case management, by digitalizing and by equipping ATAS, STAS, community social workers and helplines with the necessary competencies to fulfill their roles effectively
Description:
UNFPA is strengthening national GBV case management services delivered by ATAS, STAS and community social workers  to bolster the Moldovan government's efforts in ensuring effective protection for both Moldovans and refugees. This support includes assisting the government in the development and adoption of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for GBV case management. Additionally, UNFPA is conducting comprehensive capacity-building initiatives for ATAS, STAS and community social workers  to enhance their ability to manage GBV cases. including in a digitalized manner, effectively.
These improvements in the GBV case management services aim to benefit both local populations and refugees by ensuring that every GBV survivors has access to specialized, tailored support.

Further, UNFPA jointly with UNICEF will strengthen the helpline form women and children to respond to GBV, including technology-facilitated GBV.
Contributing partners: European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration, United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office
Implementation partners: United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Gender marker narrative: Supporting the MLSP with GBV case management, through digitalization and by equipping ATAS, STAS, community social workers, and helplines with the necessary competencies, directly contributes to the UN Gender Marker by promoting gender equality through the prevention and response to GBV, empowering women and girls, ensuring gender-responsive service delivery, and enhancing accountability in GBV programs. These actions contribute to advancing gender equality and empowerment as fundamental rights for all women and girls.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Supporting the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection (MLSP) with GBV case management, through digitalization and by equipping ATAS, STAS, community social workers, and helplines with the necessary competencies, directly contributes to the realization of human rights by ensuring the right to protection from violence, access to justice and remedy, right to health and well-being, and right to participation. Additionally, it strengthens accountability and transparency in service delivery, promoting human rights-based approaches to addressing GBV in line with international obligations.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Supporting the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection (MLSP) in digitalizing GBV case management and equipping ATAS, STAS, community social workers, and helplines with the necessary competencies contributes to the UN Sustaining Peace Empowerment Marker by enhancing the capacity of local institutions, empowering survivors of GBV, promoting social cohesion, and fostering effective, multi-sectoral responses to GBV. These efforts play a vital role in peacebuilding, conflict prevention, and ensuring that communities are resilient, stable, and inclusive.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNFPA has played a critical role in enhancing Moldova’s national protocols on gender-based violence (GBV) case management to ensure effective protection and support for both Moldovan citizens and refugees. Recognizing the increasing demand for coordinated, survivor-centered GBV services, UNFPA supported the government authorities and structures, particularly ATAS (Territorial Social Assistance Structures), STAS (Social Territorial Assistance Services), to build a more resilient and effective GBV response system.Key Contributions to GBV Case Management •  Development of a nation-wide VAW/DV case management guide, including Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) •  Objective: To establish a unified framework for GBV case management, ensuring consistent, survivor-centered, and multi-sectoral responses across Moldova.•  Scope: The SOPs outline clear roles and responsibilities for ATAS, STAS, and social workers in managing GBV cases, including identification, referral, intervention, and follow-up processes.•  Alignment with International Standards: The SOPs are informed by global best practices and tailored to Moldova’s context, integrating principles of confidentiality, safety, and respect for survivor autonomy.Comprehensive Capacity-Building Initiatives•  Scale: All community social worker (circa 1000 persons) were trained to strengthen their capacity to manage GBV cases effectively.•  Core Training Components:•  GBV Core Concepts and Survivor-Centered Care: Building understanding of GBV dynamics, survivor needs, and trauma-informed approaches.•  GBV Case Management: Training on the SOPs, including how to conduct risk assessments, develop case action plans, and ensure coordinated referrals to medical, legal, and psychosocial support.Integration of Digitalized Case Management•  Innovative Approaches: UNFPA is supporting the government in development and rollout of digital tools to streamline case management processes, reduce administrative burdens, and improve data accuracy.Features of Digitalization:•  Secure storage of case information to ensure confidentiality and protect survivor’s data.Real-time monitoring and reporting to track case progress and service delivery outcomes.

2023 Narrative: A regulation on telemedicine had been approved and enabled the use of telemedicine in the health sector. Currently, the telemedicine platform covered the most deprived regions of the country. WHO and UNFPA were joining the process to introduce telemedicine at the PHC level. The MOH was strongly coordinating this work to avoid the introduction of multiple telemedicine platforms in the health sector.UNICEF advocated for PMTCT (Prevention of mother-to-child transmission) indicators to be included into the routine HMIS (Health Management Information System). Monitoring of HMIS indicators and lab testing are helping the country to prepare for a Validation of the elimination of Mother to child transmission (MTCT) of HIV. Due to the training provided by UNICEF Supply Division on a vaccine forecasting and budgeting tool, Kyrgyzstan has witnessed notable advancements in planning and budgeting for vaccine procurement.
2024 Narrative: Introduction of the telemedicine in additional 6 rayons is part of that project with support from UNICEF. By the end of 2024, the list of rayons is selected and working groups of experts to digitalize additional clinicalprotocols are established.

2023 Narrative: To follow up on the 2022 Transforming Education Summit and the 2022 Joint Sector Review, UNICEF provided technical and coordination support to the MOES in documenting the agreed policy reform areas in the process of formulating the Partnership Compact. UNICEF was able to advance the progress of a learning recovery programme. UNICEF identified 20,000 children from Grades 5-6 in targeted 460 schools who have fallen behind in reading, math and science.  In partnership with Republican Teacher Training Center and the Online Platform “Mugalim”, UNICEF has developed a teacher training module focusing on Learning Catch-Up. This initiative aims to help 10,000 teachers (around 90 per cent female teachers) from 460 schools to gain practical knowledge, techniques and skills to identify and support students in need of assistance under the Learning Catch-Up programme.
2024 Narrative: A total of 1,023 computers were delivered to 100 scools to support digital learning, and 120 IT teachers (30 per cent female) from these schools were trained to integrate digital tools into curriculum and manage the newly provided equipment. New computers and audio-visual equipment enabled students to successfully connect and participate in the lesson.

Description: The Joint  Programme focuses on enhancement of Kyrgyzstan’s digital health information system and integrate it into a comprehensive digital health ecosystem by: (i) improving equitable access to quality healthcare through an integrated digital health system; (ii) promoting inclusive service delivery across healthcare and social protection; and (iii) expanding access to quality primary healthcare services, particularly for mothers and children, by streamlining efforts in health services digitalization.

Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Digital Development, Kyrgyz Ministry of Health, Kyrgyz Ministry of Labour, Social Security and Migration

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Older Persons, Persons With Disabilities, Women & Girls, Other, Children , Migrants
2024 Narrative: In July 2024, a specialized training course held in Germany 2024 to further support the digitalization of health information systems across Central Asia. Participants gained practical skills in integrating digital technologies into healthcare systems, covering critical topics such as digital health system integration and data management. Training programs targeted senior health policy decision-makers and technical personnel to enhance leadership in managing digital health initiatives. These programs provided insights into best practices for digital health management and technology integration. In September 2024, Kyrgyz delegates attended a training in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, focusing on HL7 FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) standards. Supported by the EU through the CARINFONET network, the program addressed interoperability challenges within Central Asia’s digital health ecosystems. Participants from Kyrgyzstan and neighboring countries gained practical insights into healthcare data exchange, fostering regional cooperation and knowledge sharing. October 2024 marked the launch of the UN’s Joint Digital Health Programme in Kyrgyzstan.

2023 Narrative: A comprehensive needs assessment of the International Legal Department of the Prosecutor General’s Office of Uzbekistan was conducted. The assessment will contribute to the development of a fully-fledged e-platform for digital transmission of international judicial cooperation requests and a smart database on international cooperation in criminal matters for registration, tracking, analyzing, and monitoring the statistics and trends in judicial cooperation requests.
2024 Narrative: Development of the Mutual Legal Assistance (MLA) platform for the swift online exchange of MLA requests between jurisdictions has been initiated as part of the Digitalization component of CASC. The platform has garnered significant interest among international counterparts and has been promoted multiple times at various international forums, such as the meeting of the Council of General Prosecutors of the Organization of Turkic States and the Council of Europe’s Committee of Experts on the Operation of European Conventions on Co-operation in Criminal Matters (PC-OC). The MLA platform is currently under development, with its launch expected in 2025.

Sub-Output: 1.3.2.12 UNECE- Enhance border crossing facilitation by digitalizing the TIR procedure
Description: Interconnecting the National Customs System of Serbia with eTIR International System in order to ensure the electronic data interchange for contactless, paperless and seamless border crossing operations, thus strengthening COVID-19 resilience. Creating a contactless, paperless and seamless border crossing operations. The project aims at strengthening COVID-19 resilience of National Customs Systems by minimizing physical contact among people in cross-border operations by facilitating the flow of goods and ensuring contactless, paperless and seamless border crossing operations. This will be done by implementing the electronic procedure of the UN TIR convention (eTIR International System) for the seamless harmonized electronic exchange of data in digital transport corridors, border crossings without physical inspection of papers, goods and vehicles.
Agencies: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
Implementation partners: Republic of Serbia Ministry of Construction,Transport and Infrastrcuture
SDG Targets: 3.6 By 2020, halve the number of global deaths and injuries from road traffic accidents.,9.1 Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.,11.2 By 2030, provide access to safe, affordable, accessible and sustainable transport systems for all, improving road safety, notably by expanding public transport, with special attention to the needs of those in vulnerable situations, women, children, persons with disabilities and older persons.

2022 Narrative: UNDP:The preparation of the workforce for future jobs that will accelerate the digital transformation and green transition of the specific economic sectors and adoption of new cutting-edge technologies is a unique attribute of UN interventions. Approach encompassed anticipation of skills, knowledge transfer from EU, prediction on the impact of the future technologies and development of mechanisms for targeted training for the workforce. Mobile App for matching the skills that youth possess has been developed to further facilitate growth of their careers. Hybrid model of training is developed. The Future Skills Centre, in addition of broad list of trainings, has been equipped with cutting edge Media Hub to produce digital content necessary for the online training courses.Several key policy processes were supported including a) design and adoption of the employment measures as part of Green Economy interventions, b) introduction of skills for future professional trainings c) transfer of knowledge on latest technology trends and d) development of regional Green Territorial Employment Pacts. Partnership with the private sector on the newly created green employment measure creates 100 new employments through financial grant for green technologies, professional trainings for future skills and mentorship in guiding green investments. The measure opens potential mobilization of private capital in a ratio 1:1.4. Supporting the green transition, UN provided concrete financing mechanism and reskilling/upskilling opportunities for companies, raising their interest in investment of private capital in new green technologies and gain access to clean energy, therefore promoting public expenditure and private capital investment in the SDGs.

Strategic priority: Sustained and inclusive economic and social development
Outcome: Outcome 1: Inclusive Prosperity
Output: Output 1.3 Enhanced policies and regulatory environment
Sub-Output: Development of Country Digital Innovation Profile
Description: In coordination with the Ministry of Information Society and Administration, the Digital Innovation Profile is being developed to provide an accurate assessment of the ecosystem's capacity and maturity. The assessment is done through a series of events in which stakeholders from the ecosystem come together to analyze the current situation and co-create appropriate solutions via flagship projects and/or initiatives, and policies designed to close the digital innovation gap. The overall aim is to strengthen the digital innovation capabilities of the country. A series of co-creation workshops will be held with North Macedonian stakeholders, from the private sector, the public sector and academia, on recommendations and the assessment of the innovation ecosystem in the country.
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Information Society and Public Administration
SDG Targets: 8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,9.b Support domestic technology development, research and innovation in developing countries, including by ensuring a conducive policy environment for, inter alia, industrial diversification and value addition to commodities.
SDG Goals: 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1 Output 1.1: Sustainable enterprises created as generators of employment
2022 Narrative: Assistance in building an ICT-centric innovation ecosystem was provided to North Macedonia, which included desktop research, the organization of national consultations, engagement of relevant stakeholders, processing a series of interviews, culminating in developing a Digital Innovation Profile, including a series of recommendations and implantable projects. A series of co-creation workshops took place in the month of June after a series of bilateral interviews were held between ITU and the individual stakeholders of the country. The first co-creation workshop on "Ecosystem Assessment Canvas” was held on 21 June 2022, and the second co-creation workshop, “Ecosystem Maturity Map”, was held on 24 June 2022. During both co-creation workshops, ITU analyzed and collected a series of relevant information to deliver an accurate analysis of the Digital Innovation ecosystems of North Macedonia to allow the country to accelerate its national agenda on digital transformation. The final co-creation workshop on the “Strategic Priority Matrix” took on Tuesday, 28 June 2022.The Digital Innovation Profile created the basis for the ICT Strategy 2023-2027.
