Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP3_Enhanced shared prosperity in a sustainable economy
Outcome: OC3_By 2027, all people of Moldova, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, competitive and sustainable economic development and equal access to decent work and productive employment
Output: OU 3.1_Policy and institutional frameworks create an empowering environment for inclusive and sustainable economic development that promotes creation of productive and decent work
Sub-Output: Digital Capacity Building of Culture and Creative Sectors in the Republic of Moldova
Description:
This project under the UNESCO-KFIT initiative “Digital Creative Lab II”, aims to support developing countries in addressing the digital skills shortages in the cultural and creative industries. This will be done by supporting the establishment of training programmes that strengthen the digital skills and competencies of the cultural and creative sectors in developing countries, and to support their full participation in the ongoing changes to the cultural value chain.
As such, the UNESCO Office in Venice shall:
Enhance the capacity of the cultural and creative sectors to promote inclusive, fair and sustainable economic development in the Republic of Moldova. Through the proposed activities, creative and cultural industries will be empowered to better face socio-economic challenges. In the long run, the project will create synergies to promote the diversity of cultural expressions in the digital environment.
Inform policy in culture and creative sectors through high quality data and information especially related to digital environment (Thematic Indicators for Culture in 2030 Agenda, and Creative Industries Festival)
Improve the digital skills and competencies of professionals in the cultural and creative sectors by providing capacity building for professionals and managers in the cultural and creative sectors, by providing digital tools and equipment to universities teaching subjects related to the creative industries, and by establishing formal cooperation and exchange of experiences with CCIs in other countries.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Culture
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,11.3 By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Normative Support, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Gender equality was mainstreamed throughout the project implementation, while the project also integrated gender-specific and gender transformative outcomes in the results framework.  For example, the Activity 1 foresaw the development of the Online registry for the CCIs where collection of sex-disaggregated data was envisaged in order to track gender equality in the cultural sector. In the same way, Activity 3 ensured to include the representatives of the diverse communities in the trainings, not to mention the balanced representation of male and female participants, as well as youth (students).
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The principle of rights-based approach is mainstreamed in the UNESCO-KFIT programme, and the programme is in line with UNESCO Gender Equality Action Plan in the context that the COVID-19 pandemic have taken a disproportionate toll on female artists and cultural professionals, even though Cultural and Creative Industries (CCIs) are among the sectors with the highest employment rate of women.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
Sustaining peace marker narrative: It focuses on skills development, with no direct link to this peace marker.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.2_Health, education and food systems are strengthened and become more resilient to ensure universal access and quality of services and respond to humanitarian needs
Sub-Output: (UNICEF - Closed) Provide technical assistance to the Ministry of Education and Research (MER) in the implementation of the (ESP) 2030, with a particular emphasis on fostering inclusiveness, gender equality, resilience, WASH, digital transformation, and financial efficiency within the education sector, addressing the needs and rights of all women/girls, men/boys, and encompassing both development and humanitarian contexts.
Description: Technical assistance to the Ministry of Education and Research (MER) in establishing an inclusive and gender-equitable education system that caters to the diverse needs of girls and boys, ensuring equal access to traditional and innovative learning opportunities for all children, including refugees, children with disabilities, children with special educational needs (SEN), and Roma children. This includes promoting gender equality, challenging stereotypes, implementing assistive technologies tailored to individual needs for girls and boys with disabilities and SEN, developing a National Programme on Digital Transformation of the Education Sector, incorporating the empowerment of girls in STEM, reviewing curricula, creating e-learning materials adapted to children with SEN, adopting child-centered methodologies, promoting inclusive education, fostering child rights, addressing mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), building resilience, fostering social cohesion, addressing climate change, and strengthening emergency response capacities at central and local levels.
Contributing partners: Croatia - Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs, Education Cannot Wait Fund, European Union, German Funds, Global Partnership for Education, Government of Italy, Government of Japan, Government of Norway, The LEGO Foundation, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration, The United Nations Partnership on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Education and Research, Moldova Ministry of Health, Moldova Republican Center for Psychopedagogical Assistance (CRAPP), Moldova local public administration, Moldova youth centers
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported MER to develop Education Development Strategy 2030, midterm Action Plan 2027 and simulation models to them. These policy documents were approved by the Government in March 2023 and have a particular focus on inclusiveness, equity, gender equality, resilience, WASH, digital transformation, and financial efficiency within the education sector, targeting both development and humanitarian contexts. To support the implementation of these policy documents, UNICEF, as lead and coordinating agency provides support to MER in the digital transformation of the sector focusing on development of policy documents, curricula, standards, training, and digital content, strengthening EMIS. To ensure equitable access of children with disabilities, Moldovan and Ukrainians, to quality education, UNICEF supported mapping of these children and identification of their individual health, protection and learning needs and follow up, UNICEF will procure assistive technologies to ensure their participation in education.

Sub-Output: Effective participation of young people in decision-making processes, especially on matters affecting their life, is encouraged through scaling-up and enhancement of the digital platform U-Report and enhancing capacity of Government and the Youth Affairs Agency
Description: Effective participation of young people in decision-making processes, especially on matters affecting their life, is encouraged through scaling-up and enhancement of the digital platform U-Report
Contributing partners: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, UNICEF Catalytic Fund, UNICEF GenU, UNICEF Other Resources
Implementation partners: Agency on Youth Affairs (Youth Union of Uzbekistan), Yuksalish
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.4 Output 1.4. Population groups at risk of being left behind are empowered to effectively participate in decision making, social cohesion, rule of law and peace-building processes at all levels
2021 Narrative: The number of U-Reporters across all regions continues to grow and has reached over 225,000 young people, making Uzbekistan the leading U-Report country in ECA region. Two additional regional Youth Committees were established in Andijan and Bukhara regions, so that now Youth Committees supporting governance of the platform and advocacy for youth participation at the local level are established in all regions of Uzbekistan. Regional face-to-face dialogues Youth-U-Report-Khokim (local governor) were conducted in Navoi and Andijan to promote youth participation in decision-making at the local level. U-Report poll results impacted several decisions made, e.g. introduction of the "Volunteer of the Year" contest to appraise young volunteers across the country, as well as planning on the youth-related programming among UN agencies.
2022 Narrative: The number of U-Reporters across all regions continues to grow and has reached over 320,000 young people. Uzbekistan remains to be the top U-Report country on the ECA region. The number of national partners regularly using U-Report is growing. Anticorruption Agency is among the new partners frequently using U-Report for assessing the changes happening in the perceptions of the populiton.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF achieved outstanding results in expanding the opportunity for over 13.5 million adolescents in Central Asia to actively engage in climate actions. Specifically, UNICEF supported the Government and Zamin Foundation in provision of the platform for adolescents and youth from five Central Asian (CA) countries to participate in the development of the Regional Strategy on Promoting Sustainable Development Culture and Engagement of Children and Youth in Climate Agenda. The Governments of the five CA states endorsed and signed the strategy, which incorporates the voices of young people, as a basis for further youth climate actions. Two young people as a part of the National Delegation presented the Strategy at COP 28 in Dubai.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Sustainable, resilient and green economic growth and resource management
Outcome: Outcome 2 - Economic Growth, Innovation and Climate Change
Output: 2.1 Employment and skills development
Sub-Output: Support to digital skills building of the elderly population
Description:
ITU is providing technical assistance to the Ministry of Infrastructure and Energy on a project to enhance Digital Skills for the Elderly. The primary objective of this effort is to conduct a comprehensive needs assessment within the targeted population and provide a strategy and thorough action plan with related activities to be implemented. The assessment will result in defining training specifications and content to enhance the digital skills of the elderly population, ensuring their ability to utilize digital government services and other online resources.
The target population is adults aged 59 and above who have been identified to often encounter challenges when adapting to and effectively utilizing the constantly evolving digital technologies.
Implementation partners: Albania Ministry of Infrastructure and Energy, International Telecommunication Union
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Sustained and inclusive economic and social development
Outcome: Outcome 1: Inclusive Prosperity
Output: Output 1.5 Sustainable and competitive rural economy
Sub-Output: National capacities for digital transformation of agriculture policy strengthened
Description: Under this project, FAO has been actively supporting the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Water Economy (MAFWE) in addressing the digital transformation needs of the agricultural sector. The goal is to ensure that digitalization efforts effectively meet the needs of both farmers and policymakers. In 2024 a situational analysis on the digital transformation needs in agriculture in North Macedonia has been completed. This foundational assessment maps the current digital ecosystem in agriculture, examining both institutional and broader sectoral capacities. It will serve as a critical basis for developing an outline of the country’s first National Strategy on Digitalization of Agriculture and will also guide FAO's technical assistance on enhancing key digital solutions of MAFWE to improve data quality, quantity, and functionality, aligning with EU approximation requirements.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, North Macedonia National Extension Agency, North Macedonia State Hydro-Meteorological Service
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: In 2024 FAO completed a situational analysis on the digital transformation needs in agriculture in North Macedonia. This foundational assessment maps the current digital ecosystem in agriculture, examining institutional and sectoral capacities. It serves as a critical basis for developing a National Strategy on Digitalization of Agriculture and guiding FAO's technical assistance in enhancing the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Water Economy’s key digital solutions. These improvements aim to strengthen data quality, quantity, and functionality, aligning with EU approximation requirements.In response to the Ministry’s additional request, a needs assessment was conducted in 2024 to support FAO’s assistance in designing a specialized digital software solution for calculating the Cost of Production (CoP) for key agricultural products in North Macedonia. The CoP is a crucial factor influencing the competitiveness of the agricultural sector, farmers' incomes, the sustainability of farming systems, and overall food production potential. It provides a key analytical tool for evaluating and comparing competitiveness across different farming systems and agricultural enterprises.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.1: Increased capacities of education stakeholders to respond to evolving learning environment including through strengthening inclusive  blended and digital learning.
Sub-Output: Leveraging technologies and digital innovations in Kazakhstan to ensure more inclusive, effective and relevant learning
Description: In Central Asia, challenges in digital literacy and skills have made the implementation of online education particularly difficult in rural and remote areas, accompanied by low availability and affordability of infrastructure and connectivity, limited capacity of rural teachers in conducting effective online learning, lack of available and accessible quality online content in national and minority languages, and limited flexibility and agility of national education systems. UNESCO Almaty will provide support to strengthening the national capacities in planning technology-enabled education systems, developing digital competencies for teachers and learners and fostering technology-enhanced pedagogies through the development of digital content. UNESCO is discussing with national partners and subordinate bodies of the Ministry of Education on identifying the further steps and joint work on strengthening the use of ICTs in education and digital skills of teachers based on the ICT readiness assessment conducted in 2021. In the quarter, there will be concrete activities identified to support Kazakhstan in the area of ICT competencies of teachers.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of High Education and Science
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: UNESCO co-organized Forum on Artificial intelligence in Education and Science jointly with the Ministry of Science and Higher Education to share about the important principles and guidelines on using AI in Education and educating on the use of AI on gender-related questions. In addition, UNESCO is supporting the development of Regional guidelines on cyber safety for teachers, which was requested by the education stakeholders at the Central Asia Symposium on ICT in Education due to the increased use of internet and social media by children and young people and potential  cyber risks. The structure of guidelines and outline has been developed, in 2023 UNESCO will develop its content and then it will be shared with teachers for their use.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and Equitable Social Development
Outcome: Outcome 1.2 By 2025, women and girls have improved and equal access to resources, opportunities and rights, and enjoy a life without violence and discrimination.
Output: Output 1.2.2 Systemic constraints hindering women’s economic empowerment are reduced, and positive business practices are implemented to transform the gender bias in the world of work.
Sub-Output: 1.2.2.20 Digital competency and entrepreneurship trainings for refugee and host community women
Implementation partners: Refugee Support Center (MUDEM)
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2021 Narrative: A total of 1127 women and girls have increased their skills to strengthen their income-generation potential through digital literacy courses provided by partners in partnership with public institutions in Gaziantep and Izmir. As part of the livelihood interventions, women from refugee and host communities have increased their skills on digital literacy through tailored courses on the fundamentals of secure internet, basic computer skills, smartphone and tablet use, electronic communication, information and data security, digital ethics, digital marketing, social media management, MS offices programs, and web design / virtual business. The digital literacy courses have been supported by short-term trainings on career planning, preparing resumes, job search, job interviews, job counselling, and other relevant soft skill sessions. In addition, Textile/Clothing/Apparel Staff Courses organized jointly with Gaziantep Chamber of Industry Vocational Training Centre have been provided to women from refugee communities. Afghan and Syrian women who successfully completed the textile/clothing apparel staff course have now become registered tailors. 13 women were engaged in income generating activities.

Sub-Output: 2023-2025 1.2.13 Localize FAO's Digital Village Initiative in Action
Description:
Under the ‘’1000 Digital Village Initiative (DVI)’’ corporate programme, FAO REU will support a holistic digital rural transformation as a means to address important challenges in the agriculture and food production sector and improve the livelihoods of rural communities.

With this project, FAO has identified two villages in BiH that have the potential to be transformed in digital villages in the recipient countries, based on REU’s DVI Readiness Assessment. These villages will serve as the pilot areas for REU’s first Digital Village Initiative interventions based on ‘village-twinning’ and other transformational activities such as enhancing digital literacy and access to markets, delivering digital rural services (advisory and information services, early warnings, e-subsidies, etc), as well as financial and insurance services; promoting digital rural champions and digital farm labs models, etc. Ultimately, FAO will support the local stakeholders to develop project proposals to mobilize the necessary resources to further accelerate villages’ digital transformation.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Alumni asocijacija inženjera elektrotehnike, BiH Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Relations, FBiH Ministry of Agriculture, Water Management and Forestry, Kakanj, Pale - Prača, RS Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Management, Zenica-Doboj Canton
SDG Targets: 9.c Significantly increase access to information and communications technology and strive to provide universal and affordable access to the Internet in least developed countries by 2020.
Geography: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Pale, Republika Srpska, Zenica-Doboj Canton, Kakanj, Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: National systems are able to effectively plan for and implement inclusive recovery
Output: Data generation
Sub-Output: Just transitions in vulnerable places - digital solutions for more climate resilient informal areas and climate smart urban recovery of communities affected by crisis
Description:
This project is being implemented in Ukraine by UN-Habitat through UNITAC, the United Nations Innovation Technology Accelerator for Cities, a joint initiative from UN-Habitat, OICT and the Hafen City University (HCU) in Hamburg.
The project engages with national, sub-national and local government institutions in support of digital urban data generation and analysis for evidenced-informed and participatory decision making by
application of diagnostic tools. These tools will be used to support the recovery of cities affected by the war in Ukraine,  hereby aligning project objectives towards localizing the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda and the New Urban Agenda.
Contributing partners: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
Implementation partners: HafenCity Universität Hamburg
SDG Targets: 11.1 By 2030, ensure access for all to adequate, safe and affordable housing and basic services and upgrade slums.,11.3 By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.,11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Normative Support, Other (including coordination), Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2022 Narrative: The project was launched with an initial work session in the form of a consultation workshop on 14th December 2022.This session aimed at outlining forward looking recommendations for a value proposition of the UNITAC Hamburg project in Ukraine, in a context where a vast array of urban stakeholders and technology-based assessment methods have emerged since the beginning of the conflict.31 participants, representing national, regional and local governments in Ukraine, UN agencies, CSOs, Academia and subject experts were invited to contribute to the discussion in a hybrid format.During the session, participants discussed the needs of cities for a sustainable recovery, the added value and limitations of existing assessments, as well as criteria for the selection of pilot cities where the project will be implemented.No costs were directly induced by this workshop as it was mostly held online.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, this project entered it's inception phase, aiming at further scoping the interventions and contextualizing existing approaches to strengthen the digital and data capacity of national, regional and local government entities to improve decision making and enable implementation of climate resilient recovery planning, reconstruction of cities and neighborhoods in Ukraine.In Ukraine, the project has made significant progress in selecting government partner institutions. The Ministry for Digital Transformation, The Ministry for Reconstruction, the Kyiv Oblast Regional Administration and six local governments – Makariv, Vassylkiv, Brovary, Boryspil, Velyka Dymerka – have expressed interest in participating in the project. Workshops on digital tools and data for climate resilient urban recovery have been held with Kyiv Oblast and Makariv and rapid planning studios making use of digital tools are being planned for Q4 2023. Additional target oblasts and municipalities are being selected in discussion with the UN-Habitat Urban Lab and the UN Durable Solutions Working Group.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Well-being, social equity and the human potential are at the heart of systems, policies and practices
Outcome: 2.1.  Universal and inclusive access to quality health, social and protection services is improved
Output: More people benefit from universal health coverage, including mental health, drug abuse prevention, and healthier lifestyles
Sub-Output: 2.1.1.9 UNICEF- UNICEF- Young child health and well-being: Improving quality of perinatal/antenatal/neonatal care including breastfeeding promotion and support;  Support MoH and IPH to strengthen national child immunization programme;  Strengthening capacities of the health system for COVID-19 response; Efficiency and quality of PHC; Migrant and refugee response in health; Supporting digitalisation of the health system; Increasing evidence and capacity on addressing enviroinmental pollution and negative impact on maternal and child health;  Development of system and services for young child parenting support on nurtiring care (responsive parenting and early learning, nutrition etc.); Development of National network of early childhood intersectoral intervention services; Strengthening co-ordinated and comprehensive support on ECD for the most vulnerable Roma communities.
Description:
Technical Assistance is provided to the Ministry of Health (in collaboration with ministries responsible for education, social policy, family and local self-governments) to:
a) Update and develop relevant standards and professional guidelines, pre- and in-service education opportunities, supervision and monitoring for medical (and ECD) professionals to ensure quality provision of services supporting child and maternal health, perinatal/antenatal/neonatal care, child immunization, early childhood development and intervention/inclusion                       
b) To increase coverage of routine immunization (including through evidence generation on root causes of low MMR coverage, digitalize data collection ad  social behavior change strategies)
c)  To scale up innovative gender-transformative integrated Early childhood development (ECD)/ Early childhood intervention (ECI) for CwD services, by strengthening policy, legal, financial, and institutional framework, including human and professional capacities of primary health care, including home visiting services, paediatricians, developmental counsel units and its crossectional collaboration with education and social welfare 
d) Improving refugees and migrants' health through strengthening capacities of medical and other professionals in transit migrant centres.
e) To improve health data management and digitalization, including collection and use of sex and age-disaggregated data.
f) To strengthen the efficiency and quality of primary health care in providing health services to mother and children and increasing resilience for public health emergencies
g) To increase evidence and capacity on addressing negative impact of environmental pollution on maternal and child health
Contributing partners: European Union, Government of Norway, LEGO foundation, Multi-Partner Trust Fund, Private Sector, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, United Nations Children's Fund, United State of America Government, World Health Organization
Implementation partners: Institute of Public Health of Serbia, National CSOs Serbia, Private Sector, Republic of Serbia Ministry of Health , Serbia Standing Conference of Towns and Municipalities
SDG Targets: 3.2 By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership

2021 Narrative: NA
2022 Narrative: To achieve project objectives, UNFPA in 2022 delivered the following results:1. Demo version of an alternative online registration module for the planned antenatal/postnatal care visits for women residing in remote areas was developed. 2. Two evidence-based clinical protocols developed and submitted to MoH Guideline  Protocol (GP) Board for approval: (a) Implementation of Tele-medicine along the continuum of maternal care with a focus on Antenatal care (ANC) and Postnatal care (PNC); (b) Safe Abortion guideline developed based on the new WHO Abortion Care Guideline (2022)3. The online registration module for cervical cancer screening - a web-based queue management system piloting in Tbilisi launched.
2023 Narrative: As a result of UNFPA efforts, in 2023 UNFPA collaboration with MoH IT Agency and the NCDC supported introduction of new service delivery approaches such as telemedicine in the SRH field, specifically in Antenatal Care (ANC) and Family Planning: (a) MoH adjusted the state ANC program to accommodate telemedicine approaches in service provision; (b) An online training module on remote delivery of ANC services has been developed and embedded into the Medical University’ Continuous Medical Education system; (c) an alternative online registration module for the planned antenatal care visits for women residing in remote areas developed; (d) an e-book for pregnant women and E-modules for parents’ classes were developed; (e) online registration module for cervical cancer screening programme was introduced countrywide resulting in over 28,300 booked visits.
2024 Narrative: Within the framework of the UN Joint Programme (JP) – "Minimizing the Impact of the COVID-19 Outbreak in Georgia Through Telemedicine and Digital Health Solutions," funded by the EU Delegation to Georgia, UNFPA has introduced innovative service delivery approaches in the Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) field, with a particular focus on Antenatal Care (ANC) and In 2024, in cooperation with the Ministry of Health's IT Agency, UNFPA implemented several key activities: (a) 252 obstetricians and gynecologists (17% of registered OB/Gyns countrywide) completed an updated ANC course, equipping them with the skills necessary to provide telemedicine-based ANC services; (b) An alternative online registration module was developed for scheduling antenatal care visits, targeting women residing in remote areas; (c) Since 2023, the total number of visits is 61,231 (particularly 34,198 visits in 2024) have been booked in total. In 2024, the target population books 22% independently (19% in 2023), 23% by primary care facilities (24% in 2023), and the rest directly by screening providers. Among those with booked appointments, 70% have undergone all screening in 2024; (d) A platform was developed to enable rural and district ANC providers to consult remotely with specialists and obtain a "second qualified opinion."; (e) An e-book for pregnant women covering pregnancy development and early childcare and e-modules for antenatal parenting classes was developed and distributed among ANC providers. The pilot implementation of these digital products commenced on December 18 in the Adjara Autonomous Republic.

2023 Narrative: WHO, jointly with the UN Population Fund (UNFPA), the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF), and the UN Office for Project Services (UNOPS), has partnered with the Ministry of Health to connect patients to primary health care, overcoming significant geographical barriers. Telemedicine can facilitate universal access to a sustainable primary healthcare system, regardless of location, and at minimal cost, utilizing digital solutions to bridge the healthcare gap for the most vulnerable communities.The programme has provided medical furniture and devices, medical supplies, and training on the usage and maintenance of equipment to ambulatory doctors across 55 municipalities in Georgia. The continued support provided to medical personnel in enhancing surveillance, data management, and contact tracing capabilities, including through the implementation of the outbreak investigation tool Go.Data, for field data collection during public health emergencies. Prioritizing critical infrastructure, the country's digital transformation has enabled patients to consult with healthcare providers and raise their awareness about health-related issues from their own homes. This advancement allows doctors to prescribe medicines, obtain additional expertise, enter immunization data, conduct ante-natal care consultations with expectant mothers, and compile reports.Regular virtual check-ins with nurses, doctors and specialists help monitor chronic conditions, identify potential health concerns early, and ensure that patients receive effective ongoing care.In this project, the WHO has formulated telemedicine clinical guidance and care pathways, outlining the requirements for running teleconsultation services associated with priority non-communicable diseases. Rural doctors are also being trained to conduct online consultations using digital medical devices, resulting in advanced competencies in telemedicine and increased skills in using digital solutions.UNFPAAs a result of UNFPA efforts, in 2023 UNFPA collaboration with MoH IT Agency and the NCDC supported introduction of new service delivery approaches such as telemedicine in the SRH field, specifically in Antenatal Care (ANC) and Family Planning: (a) MoH adjusted the state ANC program to accommodate telemedicine approaches in service provision; (b) An online training module on remote delivery of ANC services has been developed and embedded into the Medical University’ Continuous Medical Education system; (c) an alternative online registration module for the planned antenatal care visits for women residing in remote areas developed; (d) an e-book for pregnant women and E-modules for parents’ classes were developed; (e) online registration module for cervical cancer screening programme was introduced countrywide resulting in over 28,300 booked visits.

2021 Narrative: Digitalization remains one of the main focuses of UNDP governance interventions, especially related to strengthening of public services. The CO successfully implemented number of strategically important initiatives on digitalization in such areas as development of digital public services (registration of acts civil status) and building capacities of civil servants on digital management and digital economy. As a result of several high level political meetings, including on DPM level, the CO successfully used UNDP RFF opportunity to build strategic collaboration with a new partner-the Ministry of Justice (MoJ). Series of consultations with the MoJ and the Registry Office for Acts of Civil Status, helped to identify opportunities to support national partners to pilot digital public services related to registration of acts of civil status. Respective analyses on business processes were conducted to identify the ways of simplification of registration processes. Moreover, in order to assess the local IT capacities and to showcase the development a prototype of the Digital Civil Registry, two-day Hackathon first ever by UNDP was conducted with successful presentation of digital prototypes of child-birth registration with proper demonstration of front end (interface) and back-end (data base) components

2022 Narrative: 1.    Developed the technical specifications for a telemedicine platform2.    Drafted Legal/regulatory framework for Telemedicine 3.    Two key assessments were conducted on the disease surveillance systems. The first assessment examined the existing infectious diseases system to determine feasibility of its integration into the broader health information system. The second assessment mission focused on evaluating Georgia's surveillance system for COVID-19 and other respiratory viruses. The results indicated the need for robust electronic data reporting and management system for medical and laboratory data collected at sentinel surveillance sites4.    A social media campaign was organized, and with UN partners, photo stories were published to show how healthcare workers are engaged in the telemedicine service. In addition, educational posts were published on social media to educate the population about telemedicine and its benefits.
2023 Narrative: WHO supported Georgia in establishing a fully functional ArcGIS system to innovatively apply geospatial elements in addressing public health challenges. Reviewing, analyzing, and conducting in-depth research of the existing health system to provide robust/tangible recommendations for strengthening the Digital Health Information System within the MoH by promoting various digital health solutions. Conducted multi-pillar and in-depth analyses of the existing health information system and provided recommendations to strengthen the MoH's Digital Health Information System by promoting multiple digital health solutions.  Developed Key Technical Terminology and Definitions for a Comprehensive Overview of Digital Health Information Systems aiming to simplify the technical terminology used for d-HIS, empower stakeholders within the healthcare sector with a clear understanding of the technical terms associated with d-HIS, fostering informed decision-making in d-HIS implementation and contributing to the advancement of digital health in general.Developed Data Mapping of Health Systems Report to reduce duplication in data collection and enhance digitalization, data integration, and interoperability. Conducted Assessment and development of a legal framework to support interoperability of health records and to facilitate the required secondary data processing of personal health data.Conducted Cybersecurity assessment of health information systems at the ITA to identify vulnerabilities and trained staff based on the recommendation from the report Installation of outbreak investigation tool Go.Data for field data to facilitate outbreak investigation, including field data collection, contact tracing, and visualization of chains of transmission.

Description: Digitalization of state civil status records from the areas endangered by ongoing warfare, contributing to the efficiency of public services, the resilience of state registers and personal data protection.
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: The preparatory work was conducted, mainly on development of the ToR and launching the procurement process for the digitalization of the civic registers.
2024 Narrative: UNDP supported digitalization of 3,156,710 civil status records, exceeding the target of 3 million. Records from two frontline oblasts, Luhansk and Donetsk, were covered, with Luhansk achieving full digitalization. Over the past year, 22,806 individuals accessed essential civil status information through the simplified system. Additionally, the archive digitalization saved 343,431 working hours for civil status register specialists, improving service delivery speed and public service efficiency.

2024 Narrative: During 2024, the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Natural Resources of Ukraine received advanced conferencing tools to enhance coordination with diverse stakeholders.A key achievement was the Digital Waste Management Project’s initiative to raise awareness on the implementation of the Law of Ukraine "On Waste Management". This included forums held in Cherkasy (April 10–11), Dnipro (May 23–24), and Poltava (June 20–21), gathering around 800 participants (58% women) from local authorities, civil society, and communities. The forums focused on educating stakeholders about the law, presenting innovative digital waste management tools, fostering collaboration among sectors, and addressing region-specific challenges. These events highlighted legal, technical, and practical aspects of transforming Ukraine’s waste management industry.

Outcome: Outcome 2: Quality Services for All
Output: Output 2.2 Quality and affordable education
Sub-Output: Creation of digital and inclusive learning tools and resources that are in line with the pre-primary, primary and secondary education curricula
Description:
i. Provide support in preparation for PISA 2025; (UNICEF)
ii. Support initiatives for digitalization in education, including the integration of technology and artificial intelligence, to enhance the teaching process and improve the overall quality of education; (UNICEF)
iii. Support the development of tools and resources to build the skills and knowledge of educators, students, and stakeholders to promote mental well-being within the educational environment; (UNICEF)
iv. Support the development of tools and resources to prevent high dropout of Roma children in education; (UNICEF)
v. Support development of new learning resources and materials on green skilss for students in VET secondary schools; (UNICEF)
vi. Support the establishment of family oriented Early Childhood intervention services (in partnership with the Ministry of Social Policy, Demography and youth and Ministry of Health); (UNICEF)
vii. Provision of support in the development/update of relevant teaching and learning materials on comprehensive sexuality education for primary school students; (UNFPA)
viii. Development of digital informative and learning tools/products on comprehensive sexuality education (UNFPA)
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Population Fund
Contributing partners: Conflict, Stability and Security Fund, Global Education Thematic Fund, Government of the United Kingdom, Government of the United States of America, Makedonski Telekom, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Population Fund

SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 7 Output 2.2 Quality and affordable education
2021 Narrative:
Responding to the reform momentum, UNICEF supported the development and printing of textbooks for grade 1, developing digital interactive textbooks for Grade 4 and a platform for their offline and online use (E-Library) and kept building alliances and partnerships to upgrade the Eduino portal. The upgrades will allow crowdsourcing of additional teaching resources and uploading of the new interactive digital textbooks onto Eduino. In addition, Eduino was expanded with a dedicated ECD subpage and an affiliate platform for vocational secondary education.
In order to expand the programme’s reach beyond kindergarten playrooms, UNICEF is supporting the development of animated and TV content that is being broadcast nationwide and shared online, to reach children who are not attending pre-schools and help create public demand for social and emotional learning opportunities.
2022 Narrative: To support the inclusion of children with disabilities in preschool education, a digital communicator app CBoard, developed by UNICEF, was localized in Macedonian and Albanian, and a female text-to-speech voice (Suze) was developed, together with a training package on Alternative and Augmentative Communication for education professionals and parents. More than 400 professionals have thus far been trained to use these resources to support children who are facing a wide range of speech and language impairments and difficulties.Eduino– the national online learning platform established by UNICEF 2020, continues to be the main repository of educational resources for all school levels and all stakeholders, with new educational content continuously being developed for different age groups. Through crowdsourcing, the dedicated Eduino Early Childhood Development subpage was enriched with additional 1,500 digital educational games and activities developed by preschool teachers, reviewed and approved by the BDE. Moreover, a virtual science laboratory was developed in 2022, containing a section of self-paced science experiments developed as part of the programme on environment and climate change. Further resources for social and emotional learning and development for preschool-aged children were developed as part of an innovative initiative for youth engagement. The programme was implemented in 20 secondary schools with 215 students from Skopje, Gostivar, Tetovo, Radovish and Kumanovo, who worked in teams, mixed by gender and ethnicity, to jointly produce visual art, drama performances, digital games and music acts for the children in preschools, under mentorship and guidance from subject experts. 49 different products were created and the most successful ones were presented at the education conference in March. Based on this experience, a school guide was developed, offering a model for community engagement of students in secondary schools.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF supported the Bureau for the Development of Education (BDE) in taking-over complete ownership and management over the national education platform EDUINO, through capacity development, strategic discussions and operational planning. The BDE was also provided with tailored materials to inform and assist the maintenance of the EDUINO platform, as a national repository for quality, BDE-approved, free-of-charge teaching and learning materials for all students, teachers and parents in the country.Through funding and support from Sweden, UNICEF supported the establishment of the Science Learning Network (SLN), comprising of six institutions (the Hydro-biological Institute from Ohrid, Galichica National Park, Botanical Gardens in Skopje, Narodna Tehnika – Skopje, Negrevo Nature Preservation Centre and the Macedonian Ecological Society). The SLN members developed a joint educational programme, aligned with curricula and adopted by the BDE, that offers environment and climate change thematic workshops, through an experiential learning approach. To support early inclusion of children with communication difficulties, and successful transition into primary education, UNICEF continued promoting alternative and augmentative communication (AAC), through capacity development of 25 professionals at the five resource centres and introducing AACIn 2023, UNICEF supported the Bureau for the Development of Education (BDE) in taking-over complete ownership and management over the national education platform EDUINO, through capacity development, strategic discussions and operational planning. The BDE was also provided with tailored materials to inform and assist the maintenance of the EDUINO platform, as a national repository for quality, BDE-approved, free-of-charge teaching and learning materials for all students, teachers and parents in the country.To support early inclusion of children with communication difficulties, and successful transition into primary education, UNICEF continued promoting alternative and augmentative communication (AAC), and the communicator app Cboard, through capacity development of 25 professionals at the five resource centres. Moreover, AAC was introduced as a topic in the Programme for Professional Development of Educational Assistants, adopted by MoES in 2023. To support further uptake of AAC, 11 local open events were organised in preschools, to familiarise parents, ECD and ECE professionals with the benefits of AAC, and with available resources. in the Programme for Professional Development of Educational Assistants, adopted by MoES in 2023. To support further uptake of AAC, 11 local open events were organised in preschools, to familiarise parents, ECD and ECE professionals with the benefits of AAC, and with available resources.
2024 Narrative: To support the development of healthy nutrition habits from an early age, in partnership with the Ministry of Social Policy, Demography and Youth, UNICEF supported the development of a training manual on healthy nutrition for preschool staff, by experts in nutrition, health, food safety, early childhood education and development and preschool practitioners. The training manual contains a general module for all staff (preschool teachers, caregivers, kitchen staff, professional team etc) and a module with pedagogical approaches for teaching young children about nutrition, aimed specifically for preschool teachers. A set of practical information materials for parents were also developed, to foster healthy nutrition habits at home. To support the right of every child to attend quality education with their peers and in their local community, UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education and Science to develop Guidance on the Development and Implementation of the Modified Programme for Children with Complex Needs. The Guidance was developed by a working group of experts, practitioners and policy makers and it is currently pending adoption by the Minister of Education and Science. As part of efforts to support the integration of holistic and comprehensive environment and climate change education across the education system, in partnership with the Vocational Education and Training (VET) Centre, UNICEF supported the development of ten green curricula for ten different VET profiles, with accompanying learning materials. The new curricula and learning materials help students develop appropriate skills, knowledge, behaviors, and attitudes to cope with a rapidly changing world and climate. Moreover, through the development of green skills, students can contribute to personal and systemic transformation towards more sustainable lifestyles and facilitate the transitioning to a green economy.UNFPA: Digital tool for sexuality education for youth with autism spectrum disorder and intelectual disability has been developed, and will be further tested and promoted among special educators, teachers and parents of children with disabilities in 2025. The content is developed in a way that is easy to understand, with a lot of visuals / illustrations and simple text / description, to support the learning of girls and boys.

Description: Upon request of the country, ITU has launched the Digital Skills Assessment technical assistance in Q4 2021. The outcomes of this initiative will contribute to the development of a national digital skills strategy. The program includes a national assessment, a series of interviews, workshops, and others. The assessment will focus on reviewing and evaluating digital skills in the private sector, academia, and the general public. It will result in a series of recommendations and suggestions to be considered during the further development of the digital strategy. The assessment will be launched in 2022.
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Information Society and Public Administration

Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: The National Digital Skills Assessment for North Macedonia has been completed upon the request of, and in collaboration with, the Ministry of Information Society and Administration. The purpose of the report was to assess the current supply and demand of digital skills in North Macedonia, to contribute to the development of a digital skills strategy that will meet citizen needs, and to contribute to further growth of the digital economy and digital society. The assessment results are delivered in a set of explicit and implementable recommendations. The scope includes, in particular, an assessment of basic digital skills in the private sector, start-ups, and the education sector, as well as an assessment of the current demand for all levels of digital skills across the economy. The recommendations provided strategic guidance to the National ICT Strategy 2023-2027.

Plan name: Turkmenistan UNSDCF 2021 - 2025
Strategic priority: Priority B. Inclusive, green, and sustainable economic growth
Outcome: Outcome 2. By 2025, conditions for sustainable and inclusive economic diversification are strengthened with competitive private and financial sectors, enhanced trade and investment promotion, and the adoption of new and digital technologies
Output: Output 2.2. Human, institutional, and R&D capacity of public institutions and private sector strengthened for effective realization of the comprehensive programmes on diversification and digitalization of all sectors of economy with the focus on vulnerable groups
Sub-Output: Support to the establishment of digital land cadastre in Turkmenistan
Description:
The project "Support to the establishment of digital Land Cadastre" will provide support to the MAEP and its Land Resources Service, which is specifically in charge of cadastre, land use monitoring and control, and land management, with an assessment of the current policy, legal and institutional framework related to land administration and land management. 
The project will take the first (pilot) step in support of a new geocentric coordinate system and geodetic reference network of Turkmenistan, preparation of a long-term strategy (roadmap) for a modern digital geospatial data infrastructure in Turkmenistan, and implement a comprehensive training programme to upgrade the knowledge of the Land Resources Service technical staff. 
The project’s provided policy recommendations will be in line with the Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible Governance of Tenure of Land, Fisheries and Forests in the Context of National Food Security (VGGT) and promote secure tenure rights and support the broader development of small family farms.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Turkmenistan Ministry of Environment Protection
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 2 Zero Hunger, 9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
Geography: Ahal Province, Ashgabat, Balkan Province, Daşoguz Province, Lebap Province, Mary Province, Turkmenistan
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Normative Support, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: Under the TCP/TUK/3901 "Support to the establishment of digital Land Cadastre" project following activities have been done.- Review policy, legal and institutional frameworks - Prepare a draft roadmap (strategy)- Develop criteria for selection of the most suitable pilot areas- Procure and install the GNSS reference station- Real property registration and cadastre business processes re-engineered for digital operations- Pilot area with real property rights digitally captured and recorded- Conduct farm structures assessment in a selected pilot area- Organize and implement a training courseTraining on the use of Remote Sensing/GIS for land cover and crop monitoring.The Government of Turkmenistan continues to maintain the traditional system of state orders or quota. Under this system, the lease contracts specify the crop that each leaseholder (private farmer) is required to produce (typically cotton or wheat) and set a specific quantity target for delivery to the state. The LRS and its branch offices and affiliated organizations such as planning institute “Ghiprozem” undertake field verification/inspections to oversee fulfilment of the state quota.Knowledge and skills obtained through the training will help the LRS of the MAEP to building a more efficient system for forecasting and monitoring agricultural quotas by using GIS/RS technologies.  In preparation for the trip to Ashgabat of the technical mission in accordance with TCP/TUK/3901, from 20 to 24 November 2023, presentation materials were prepared for a series of training seminars on the following topics:1.  Modern GNSS technologies and their application in geodesy and cadastre. Introduction and overview of the program. 2.  Fundamentals of GNSS. Basics and trends for the Use of Global Navigation Satellite Systems in Geodesy, Cadastre and Surveys.3.  Coordinate systems in the GNSS era.4.  State-of-the-art geodetic infrastructure based on GNSS. GNSS Station Networks (CORS).5.  Technologies and methods of high-precision satellite positioning for solving problems of land cadastre and geodesy. 6.  Lecture for students and lecturers at the Agricultural University of Turkmenistan. Fundamentals of GNSS. Basics and trends for the Use of Global Navigation Satellite Systems in Geodesy, Cadastre and Agriculture.
2024 Narrative: Under the TCP/TUK/3901 "Support to the Establishment of Digital Land Cadastre" project, several key activities have been completed:International Consultant Missions:8-12 April 2024: An international consultant organized a meeting with the project's technical working group and conducted a two-day training seminar on land cadastre, CORS deployment, and the implementation of a new open coordinate system for Turkmenistan. The mission also assessed the progress of the digital land cadastre information system, ensuring alignment with international practices and standards. Discussions included the roadmap for digital land cadastre development, and a field visit to the Goktepe district was conducted for practical GNSS equipment exercises, meetings with local stakeholders, and discussions on farm structures and cadastre record digitalization.30 September - 4 October 2024: Another international consultant mission supported the ongoing technical assistance project and introduced a new initiative for strengthening crop monitoring through remote sensing technology. A two-day training seminar on remote sensing for crop monitoring was held, and the mission included a Technical Working Group meeting focused on developing a digital land cadastre strategy. A field visit to the Goktepe district was also organized to discuss cadastre record digitalization and the use of GNSS equipment in land surveying with Land Resources Service staff.Project Progress and Developments:The project has developed a strategy (Roadmap) for the digital land cadastre, outlining roles, responsibilities, funding sources, and targets, aiming for official adoption by aligning with national legislative standards.A "Procedure for Cadastral Division of the Territory of Turkmenistan and Assignment of Cadastral Numbers" has been developed in line with the Law of Turkmenistan "On State Land Cadastre" and Article 36 (4), ensuring each land parcel is uniquely and persistently identified.A technical report on "Turkmenistan GNSS Measurements and CORS Network Processing" has been produced, detailing parameters and strategies for GNSS measurement processing, marking significant progress in establishing the TmPOS network.Recommendations for a new open coordinate system have been developed, outlining the implementation strategy and technical parameters for the geocentric coordinate system, essential for modernizing land administration, enhancing land governance, and supporting various economic sectors.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Social cohesion, people-centered governance, rule of law and human rights
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from improved social cohesion, increased realization of human rights and rule of law and accountable, gender-responsive institutions
Output: 4.2. Public administration, data and digitalisation
Sub-Output: Supporting Digital Transformation in Montenegro
Description:
The Government of Montenegro is determined on furthering the reform of the public sector, making it more accountable, transparent, inclusive, and efficient and effective service to the citizens and the society. 
This Project, following the request of the Ministry of Public Administration of the Government of Montenegro, has been designed to enable enhancement of eGovernment and eServices. 

Amendment of the Project Agreement is signed on 26 December 2024 and it contains three additional outputs:
1. Development of studies for the improvement of digital capacities and systems of the Government;
2. Assessment framework for the evaluation of local self-governments’ performance established;
3.Analysis of current digital touristic data flow.
During the implementation of the basic Agreement (January-December 2024), two outputs have been delivered: E Government Assessment of the Local Self Governments and Feasibility study for the construction of the State Data Center and Disaster Recovery Center. 

The amended activities will be implemented in close cooperation with the Ministry of Public Administration and its Directorate for Infrastructure, Information Security, Digitalisation and e-Services and the Ministry of Tourism. 

The results and activities related to eGovernment and eServices at the local level are complementary with actions of the “Digital Transformation of Local Self-Governments in Montenegro” Project, which is funded through the Montenegro Sustainable Development Goals Acceleration Fund (MAF)
Agencies: United Nations Office for Project Services
Contributing partners: Montenegro Ministry of Public Administration Montenegro
Implementation partners: Ministry of Economic Development and Tourism Montenegro, Montenegro Ministry of Public Administration Montenegro

2023 Narrative: Within the Phase 2 of the Akelius literacy programme, UNICEF doubled the number of schools to 18 to reach over 2,000 children by May 2025. The programme is already benefitting over 700 children and improved technology skills in over 50 teachers.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF’s Akelius literacy program benefitted over 1,800 children in 18 schools in disadvantaged neighborhoods. Around 200 of these children are migrants from China, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. To address educators’ needs, intensive year-long capacity building was conducted for 84 teachers to improve their digital teaching skills

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF further supported the GIGA initiative on schools’ connectivity in partnership with the MDDIAI and MoE, with focus on new connectivity standards, launch of market assessment of satellite-based solutions and scale up of the Daily Check application to 5,100 schools to monitor the internet speed. UNICEF supported schools in using the Internet to develop digital and language literacy and to enhance modern teaching methods in blended learning. UNICEF is supporting schools to develop internal connectivity infrastructure. For schools with low internet speeds or not connected to broadband, new technical solutions, last mile connectivity and funding models are being explored to address this issue and bridge the digital divide. CO launched a market assessment for satellite-based connectivity solutions to provide more evidence to the government on costs, Internet providers’ profiles and case studies from Canada, China and Finland.
2024 Narrative: The Internet speed monitoring Daily Check App covered 6,916 schools out of 7,833, which contributed to raise schools’ national internet speed average from 13 to 19 mbps when uploading. UNICEF conducted a market assessment for satellite-based solutions for connecting remote rural primary and secondary schools to broadband Internet

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.2: Improved knowledge and life skills of People of Kazakhstan, especially vulnerable groups for sustainable development, well-being and resilience.
Sub-Output: Women and girls living in rural areas of Kazakhstan enhanced their skills in digital literacy and STEM
Description: Implementation of an initiative to strengthen digital literacy and STEM skills of young women and girls living in rural areas of Kazakhstan with the aim of empowering them in the field of information technology and encouraging them to study in STEM fields
Implementation partners: UN Women
SDG Targets: 5.b Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: More than 30 girls, 8th-grade students from M. Kurmanov School in the village of Balpyk Bi, Zhetysu region, had strengthened their skills in the field of STEM (natural sciences, technology, engineering, mathematics) during a training held on November 13-14, 2024. Supported by the international IT software development company EPAM, the training aimed at building the potential of girls by enhancing their knowledge and skills to address the gender gap in technology. Throughout the training, the girls advanced their understanding in STEM fields, 3D modeling, programming, robotics, and digital security, while also developing skills in teamwork, self-presentation, and creative thinking. Additionally, the participants underwent career guidance testing and received individual consultations from leading experts to identify their strengths and assist in making informed career choices. According to the testing results, the majority of the girls expressed an interest in STEM fields, with 60% indicating a desire to further develop skills in technology.
