"
2022 Narrative: UNDP initiated the process of development of a digital platform for mobile and Internet banking for the purposes of digital transformation in the banking sector. The digital platform will enhance digital banking services for both retail and corporate clients. To implement the digital transformation component of the bank - Internet and Mobile Banking platform and the HCE for Mobile Bank module, integration with the existing environment and technical support in the TFEB,
2023 Narrative: In the area of development of the financial, economic, and banking sectors, the development of a software for innovative digital banking platform that will expand the range of online financial services for corporate and retail clients was completed and now is in the process of integration with other banking digital platforms: core banking and cards processing. UNDP also organized series of capacity building webinars on such topics as E-Money, Open Banking, Development of Payment Systems, Fast Payment Systems, Digital Currencies, etc. The launch of the digital banking faces challenges related to integration of the digital solution with other banking solutions (core banking and cards processing platforms) due to necessity to upgrade these platforms, which lays outside of project scope and should be resolved by the national partner. Moreover, challenges remain with introduction of innovative financial and banking instruments in the absence of smoothly functioning macroeconomic system.
2024 Narrative: The online banking software has been developed and will launch January of 2025.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.2: Improved knowledge and life skills of People of Kazakhstan, especially vulnerable groups for sustainable development, well-being and resilience.
Sub-Output: Leveraging technologies and digital innovations in Kazakhstan to ensure more inclusive, effective and relevant learning
Description: The overall purpose is to ensure more inclusive, effective and relevant learning by leveraging technologies and digital innovations in Kazakhstan. More than ever before, the importance of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) and digital innovations have been highlighted by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on education and learning. In this context, UNESCO will provide its support to Kazakhstan with development of policy recommendations, learning and teaching materials as well as capacity building in such areas as ICT in education, using AI in education, ensuring cyber safety and cyber security. In addition, UNESCO will ensure a knowledge sharing and exchange platform in the area of ICT in education and cyber security with other countries in the region. With the support of Korea Education, Research and Information Service of the Ministry of Education, UNESCO will facilitate the capacity building and knowledge exchange between Korea and Kazakhstan in the field of ICT in education and cyber security.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: Republic of Korea Ministry of Education
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Information-Analytic Center, Kazakhstan Ministry of Education, Kazakhstan higher education institutions
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,4.6 By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, and achieve literacy and numeracy.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
LNOB groups targeted: Women & Girls, Youth, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Children , Minorities, Migrants, Persons With Disabilities, Older Persons
2024 Narrative: UNESCO in partnership with Korea Education Research and Information Service (KERIS) supported the Ministry of Education with the technical assistance to identify the scope of cyber security, and associated risks and challenges faced by pupils, teachers and parents on a national level and plan the next steps to effectively support learners’ interaction with the online world. Within this project, the scoping mission was conducted with partcipation of KERIS and UNESCO experts to Astana to assess the current situation on digital learning and cyber safety, which included the meetings with the key education stakeholders and site-visits to schools. As a result, the report is being prepared with key policy recommendations on digital skills development with the focus on cyber safety, which will be shared with the Ministry of Education. In addition, as part of the project, 3 education policy makers participated in the study visit to South Korea to learn the Korean best practices in education data management, digital skills and cyber safety. UNESCO has also initiated a new project on integrating media and information literacy (MIL) into curriculum with the National Academy of Education of the MoE in 2024 and plans to build capacity of curriculum developers and teachers on integrating MIL into curriculum and education standards.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025

Sub-Output: Training and supporting teachers in Kazakhstan to improve learning outcomes and address the changes brought forth by the digital and artificial intelligence (AI) transformation and the COVID-19 crisis
Description: Overall purpose is to address learning loss due to the Covid-19 crisis and improve of learning outcomes in Kazakhstan through the provision of policy support on teachers, training and supporting teachers and developing teaching and instructional materials. This will help teachers to provide adequate remediation and deliver different modalities of learning in order to address learning loss and improve learning outcomes.  UNESCO will provide support in building capacity of teachers in the fields of ESD, ICT in education, including cyber safety and healthy lifestyles. With the support of Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Kazakhstan, teachers from rural schools will be supported to create professional learning circles and develop non-positional leadership with the purpose of addressing the quality of learning outcomes.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Education, Kazakhstan higher education institutions, Republican Centre for up-grading Teachers' education "Orleu"
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Data Collection and Analysis, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 3 - Sustaining Peace is the principal objective
LNOB groups targeted: Minorities, Persons With Disabilities, Migrants, Children , Youth, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Women & Girls
2024 Narrative: -         UNESCO Almaty in partnership with HertsCam (UK), TeachersLab and Kazakh National Women’s Teacher Training University initiated the pilot project on Rural and Remote Schools (RARS) to create professional learning communities through development of non-positional teacher leadership in 11 pilot schools in 3 regions of Kazakhstan, as a priority identified by the Government of Kazakhstan.-         The aim of the current project (RARS) is to empower and enable rural teachers to take the initiative to develop strategies to overcome the challenges of the teaching profession in remote rural schools and create professional learning communities among the teachers.-         6 network events were hosted by 11 schools in Almaty, Mangystau, and Atyrau provinces where the teachers could share their projects, findings and insights and explore the new ways of solving their problems with the peers.-         128 teachers and 22 facilitators enhanced their professional development and expanded their leadership potential through the creation of professional learning communities.-         A research report on the project will be developed in 2025 to disseminate knowledge with the government of Kazakhstan and scale up the project nationwide.Digests of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan national reports on teacher policies were finalized for dissemination. The reports have been previously developed by UNESCO in partnership with the World Bank. Digest reports identify the strengths and weaknesses in the system and structure the knowledge exchange to inform and support improvements in teacher policy in the respective countries.

2023 Narrative: For supporting digitalization of agriculture in Kyrgyztsan review and analysis of public services and business processes of the Ministry of Agriculture of the Kyrgyz Republic and development of recommendations for the automation of business processes and digitalization of public services were provided. Qualitative research and analysis to support in conceptualization of “Digital Villages Farmer Service Center” model elaborated.FAO in close collaboration with UNFPA organized Issyk-Kul - Agro-Hackathon collected 5 best IT solutions to increase efficiency of agro- production and processing. Three-day intensive educational event in the format of a boot camp, with over 85 participants, including women/youth from target regions, mentors, and a delegation from Uzbekistan. The Agro-Hackathon in Kyrgyzstan elevated women and youth’s understanding of the IT industry, helping them apply digital strategies to advance small business across sectors, thereby sharpening their entrepreneurial skills with expert guidance.Khonobod, Andijan - IT camp united youth from Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan into interest-based groups, building their digital skills through acceleration programs, empowering them to seek solutions to GBV, food-, nutrition- and climate-security. Thus, challenging stereotypes about the roles young girls can and should play in the digital landscape and decision-making.
2024 Narrative: In Kyrgyzstan, at MWAP’s request, FMM/GLO/171/MUL analyzed eGovernment agriculture services, updated NCAPDA, and developed a concept for farmer service centers. It also provided governance and organizational recommendations for agriculture digitalization within the ministry.

A national study on "Towards Sustainable Trade in the SPECA Region: opportunities and challenges of integrating the Sustainable Trade Principles in the region" The national study contributes to shaping sustainable trade policies in the SPECA region. Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote prosperity and resilience for all citizens through inclusive and equitable green socio-economic development (GREEN SOCIO-ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT)
Outcome: By 2027, the well-being of the population of the Kyrgyz Republic will have improved through the further rollout of a green economy based on sustainable and healthy food systems natural resource management, and effective migration processes, by accelerating the use of gender transformative social and technological innovations and entrepreneurship
Output: Gender transformative social and technological innovations, including digitalization, are introduced to develop a green and creative economy
Sub-Output: The adoption and dissemination of digital and green technologies are supported to create decent jobs and build skills.
Description: The adoption and dissemination of digital and green technologies are supported to create decent jobs and build skills.
Contributing partners: Finland Ministry for Foreign Affairs, The Joint SDG Fund
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Digital Development, Kyrgyz Ministry of Economy and Commerce
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,8.8 Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Geography: Jalal-Abad, Chui, Issyk-Kul, Naryn (city), Nookat, Uzgen, Osh, Naryn, Osh (city), Naryn, Issyk-Kul, Bishkek (city), Karakol (city), Kyrgyzstan, Talas, Batken
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
LNOB groups targeted: Women & Girls, Migrants, Persons With Disabilities, Youth
2023 Narrative: a. A research on the situation of the creative economy in the Kyrgyz Republic has been conducted. The incubation of creative industries was conducted on a pilot basis in Osh city. In this regard, through partnership with local NGO - Women's Peace Bank, a wide range of information campaign on the creative industry conducted among practitioners, communities of practice in Osh city. Information campaign covered youth activities of Osh State University, local NGOs and young activists of Osh city, craftsmen of Osh city, producers of souvenirs, artists, musicians, performers, actors, designers, etc. As a result, 31 applications received, of which a creative event "RYTHM of the city" was selected together with the Mayor's Office of Osh city and the Association of Creative Industry. On April 8, 2023, the city of Osh hosted the “Rythm of the City” Creative Industries Festival. More than 400 people attended the event. The event brought together representatives of more than 30 communities of creative industries practitioners. There were two panel discussions, on creative economy and green development. A fair was held, where local artisans had the opportunity to sale their products. There were master classes in more than 10 areas. The festival aimed to promote dialogue between different cultures and ethnic groups. The Osh mayor’s office committed to conduct such Creative Festivals on annual basis.b. A total of 1374 applications received from Osh (536), Jalal-Abad (430), Batken (365) and other (14) provinces. Out of total applicants 150 girls have been selected based on the following criteria such as large families, families with people with disabilities, children of migrants, socially vulnerable families, single mothers, orphans, unemployed. The selected 150 girls have chosen the following Digital and IT-courses. At the end 87 young girls were successfully employed. The largest number of employed persons is observed in the areas of SMM (30 persons) and mobilography (26 persons), Front End- (6 person), UX/UI design – (4 person) and Tilda website builder courses – (10 person), Graphic Design stands out with (11 person) employed. Out of 87 - 47 graduates are self-employed, including freelancing and working on individual contracts for entrepreneurs, 40 of the graduates work as part-time employees in public institutions or private firms. UNDP supported the Association of E-commerce in organizing the E-commerce Forum gathering more than 650 participants, 289 of them are women, from the public, private and development sectors. Participants had an opportunity to learn about emerging trends and opportunities in the sector, exchange ideas and knowledge, as well as network. Topics included digital technologies in e-commerce, marketplaces, financial payments services, etc.In addition, during the annual information campaign Export Caravan 2023 – that was dedicated to China as an export destination – 289 MSMEs (out of which 79 women) gained knowledge about benefits, opportunities and the how of exporting to China through e-commerce, including via platforms such as Pinduoduo, Taobao, JD.
2024 Narrative: UNDP has introduced gender-transformative innovations and advanced digitalization to foster a green and creative economy. In 2024, around 1000 MSMEs were supported in honey, adventure tourism, and dried fruit sectors, resulting in 70 new jobs (38 for women) and contracts exceeding $25M. These efforts empowered women entrepreneurs, strengthened green value chains, and promoted inclusive economic growth, demonstrating the transformative impact of gender-responsive programming.In partnership with the Ministry of Digital Development, UNDP advanced the national digital agenda, championing artificial intelligence (AI) within the Turkic States and supporting the mid-term national strategy on digital skills. These initiatives address the digital divide, equipping women and vulnerable populations with essential digital competencies. Additionally, a joint programme with WHO, UNICEF, and UNFPA initiated a digital maturity assessment of the Ministry of Health, promoting inclusivity and transparency in healthcare systems while strengthening global-aligned laboratory information systems. These actions underscore UNDP’s commitment to equity, innovation, and sustainable development.

2023 Narrative: 20 companies (the majority women-led) were supported in 2023 with in-depth activities on access to digital markets. Scope of support included: onboarding and individual coaching for work on Foursource European textile and garments sourcing platform; own website optimization and individual coaching for reaching consumers from the EU; shops creation and optimization on eBay platform; social media accounts optimization. Collaborated with the Association of e-commerce and government bodies to share best international practices on MSMEs support in e-commerce (study tour to the UAE and to Kazakhstan, together with MSMEs). ITC, in collaboration with Kyrgyz Economic University, has unveiled the national platform https://kg-export.learning-solutions.cloud/. This Virtual Learning System (VLS) aids startup exporters from Kyrgyzstan in adhering to cross-border trade standards and regulations, facilitating their entry into new foreign markets. The comprehensive training program encompasses courses spanning international trade rules, quality assurance, compliance requirements, export procedures, diverse trade routes, transportation modes, and specific trade protocols within Central Asia (CA), the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU), and European Union (EU) countries. The KEU attracted 747 users who enrolled on the KGZ VLS platform, with 523 successfully obtaining certification. 100+ MSMEs were trained in 2023
2024 Narrative: Building upon the February 2022 MoU between the Kyrgyz Economic University (KEU) and the ITC, KEU supported MSMEs in mastering regional and international trade procedures. Through the Virtual Learning Space (VLS) platform, participants gain practical knowledge of trade management and regulatory compliance essential for successful market access. In February 2024 KEU launched the "Marathon of Knowledge" regional VLS Contest to enhance Cross-Border Management Curriculum adoption across Central Asia. The Kyrgyz Economic University, as the institutional partner, successfully certified 750 participants through the VLS platform in 2024

The project will focus on improving the health insurance system, improving the quality of services for the insured, as well as improving the adaptability and efficiency of health services, with a special focus on women and informal workers who do not have access to equal health opportunities due to the lack of registration in the compulsory social security system. 2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued to partner with the Ministry of Education (MOE) and other national stakeholders in advancing 21st century skills. Special focus was on integrating social-emotional skills into the common secondary and higher vocational education.The Universal 21st Century Skills Concept was developed by experts from leading national institutions in cooperation with international experts. Joint work allowed to align the Concept with international guidelines and better define the strategic directions, mechanisms, and conditions for the formation of universal competencies of children and young people at different levels of education. The Concept embraced the general framework of the universal 21st century competencies developed within Belarus educational system, with a particular focus on social-emotional skills (SES). Based on the Concept, an Action Plan to build SES in Children and Young People for 2023-2026 was drafted. The Action Plan clearly defined the main interventions and implementing partners for each block and was submitted to the MOE for endorsement.International expertise was highly appreciated by the National Institute of Education (NIE) and the Republican Institute of Professional Education (RIPE) during development of the SES ME tool comprising 25 criteria and 94 indicators to measure 3 main SES components: emotional regulation, communication, and cooperation. The ME tool was co-created with adolescents from technical vocational colleges who provided recommendations and feedback. The tool will be piloted in 2024.To ensure the quality and sustainability of the SES integration in the education process the SES normative framework was supplemented by development of an in-service training programme for general secondary and technical vocational education teachers and methodological recommendations for different groups (e.g. teachers, administrations, parents) on how to integrate SES in the education process in schools and colleges.The in-service training programme for pedagogues was complemented with a curriculum for an elective courses on advancement of social-emotional skills among 3-4th and 6th-7th grade students and trainer guide developed by the NIE. The programme for pedagogues and the curriculum for school students will be piloted in 2024.

2021 Narrative: Assessment of policy and regulatory frameworks for telecommunication/ICT accessibility for persons with disabilities, development of online trainings for PWD including children and youthTraining for teachers of informatics on educating children with hearing impairments in ICT
2023 Narrative: 1) Assistive and specialized computer equipment was procured for Information and training centers for children with hearing impairments in Minsk and Vitebsk.2) In partnership with the Belarusian State Academy of Communications and the Institute of Inclusive Education at the Belarusian State Pedagogical University named after M.Tank, ITU cоducted a regional study entitled 'Methodological bases for digital upskilliing of people with disabilities' aimedd at raising awareness on the matter of digital inclusion of people with disabilities, facilitating development of national programms/trainings for digital upskilling of people with disabilities, and promoting further establishment of a network of training centres for persons with disabilities The study contains:an overview of the existing educational programs on digital upskilling, relevant methods and assistive technologies;an anlysis of access to education for different categories of people with disabilities;an overview of public and private programmes to facilitate employment of persons with disabilities;list of professions available for employment of various categories of persons with digital disabilities;recommendations for decision-makers, educational institutions and private sector on digital upskilling of people with disabilities to ensure their proper digital citizenship and employment.9 countries of the CIS Region took part in the research.3) Two Belarus’ experts participated in the regional roundtable on digital accessibility (December 2023, Moscow). Participants shared experience of running the work of the training centers for people with disabilities and their crucial role in empowering PWD through education and skills development; learned about approaches to creating inclusive digital environments in smart cities and communities; discussed challenges and opportunities for digital inclusion of PWD in the CIS region; made recommendations on promoting digital accessibility in urban areas while smart cities development, on developing volunteering and mentoring programs.4) In partnership with the United Institute for Informatics Problems of the Belarus’ Academy of Sciences, ITU ensured translation into Russian of the ITU online training course "Smart for all: beyond smart cities, building inclusive and digitally accessible environments and communities". The course is designed to present the key elements of creating inclusive, smart, sustainable, and digitally accessible cities, environments, and communities and consists of four modules: 1) Inclusive and digitally accessible environments and communities (key principles of inclusivity in the digital environment and their role in creating smart cities and communities), 2) Key elements towards building inclusive and digitally accessible environments and communities, 3) Challenges and opportunities for inclusive and digitally accessible environments and communities, 4) Resources to help build inclusive and digitally accessible environments and communities to meet the needs of present and future generations. The course is designed to provide the attendees with an understanding of the key role of digital accessibility and inclusivity, as well as gain the skills to create inclusive smart cities and communities.

In Kazakhstan, 400 migrants were interviewed (50 from Kyrgyzstan, 50 from Tajikistan, and 300 from Uzbekistan). For recipients of remittances, we interviewed 700 respondents in total (150 in Kyrgyzstan, 250 in Tajikistan, 300 in Uzbekistan, and 100 in Kazakhstan).
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan National bank

Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, United Nations Development Programme
Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Agriculture
SDG Targets: 5.a Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Quarter 1-2:
Preparatory work on automatization of vertical drainage well in Turkestan region is in the process with further scaling up by Kazvodkhoz on 503 wells; 
An automatization of installations of water management devices for farmers (Almaty region, water flow meter) has been initiated to calculate water balance; An automatized data base for calculating tariff (differential tariffication) based on earlier developed methodology has been successfully launched
From FAO side: Action and capacity plans were developed, and the needs of the farmers are being identified. Since July 2021, through the call that was published in the UN Kazakhstan and Ministry of Agriculture websites, the team has started to collect the good and innovative solutions that has been successful in advancing the digital transformation of agriculture in Kazakhstan. 
Quarter 3:
The institutional capacity of key quasi state institution in water management   RSE “Kazvodkhoz" has been improved through the elaboration of the new state programme on the development of institution 2020-2030. This programme envisages enhancement of the capacities of “Kazvodkhoz" to improve irrigation water accessibility to farmers, water users and land partitioners, to promote smart water technologies in agriculture.
Demonstrated project of automatization of irrigation water supply and vertical drainage wells to support farmers to cope with salinization and underground water is under development (services procurement stage).
Automatization of irrigation water tariff calculator was implemented to support farmers to transfer to differential tariff system.
Recommendations to mainstream remote sensing technology in irrigation water supply systems was provided to RSE “Kazvodkhoz” for farmers to determine the irrigation norm. 
Knowledge management hub (online platform) for water users and farmers was developed at the corporative website of the RSE “Kazvodkhoz”.
Two modern farmers-oriented water extension centers in Almaty and Turkestan regions have been established. 
Quarter 4:
Through 31 training workshops more than 2,311 beneficiaries in the Turkistan and Almaty regions were trained. The project has also conducted 36 expertise working meetings and field trips to design and elaborate needed equipment and conducted technological needs assessment for setting up a process of e-billing and automatization as well application of different water saving agro-technologies.

Description: Capacity-building and technical assistance in the development of digital skills curricular, disabled-accessible and gender-sensitive training materials and methodologies, creation of inclusive and accessible learning environment.
Contributing partners: International Telecommunication Union, Uzbekistan IT Park
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan IT Park, Uzbekistan Ministry of Digital Technologies, ZTE Corporation
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 4.2 Output 4.2. By 2025, Government and other educational stakeholders have increased capacity to provide access to equitable, inclusive, safe and quality education at all levels and promote lifelong learning in an integrated manner, including quality professional development system and decent work environment for education sector employees
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Persons With Disabilities, Other, Women & Girls
2021 Narrative: (1) Regional baseline assessment on digital accessibility is conducted and published (https://www.itu.int/pub/D-PHCB-ICT_ACCESS_CIS.01-2021); online training courses on web-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/web-accessibility-cornerstone-digital-societyon-line-self-paced-training-0) and ICT-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/ict-accessibility-key-inclusive-communication-line-self-paced-training) are translated into Russian. The principles of the accessible web resources design are localized in Uzbekistan by means of the development of “Recommendations for ensuring the accessibility of web content" (jointly with “IT-Academy" LLC of Uzbekistan and the Association of Disabled Persons of Uzbekistan). These Recommendations can be used to improve the accessibility of websites of government agencies, businesses, social services, universities and other organizations and are aimed at creating inclusiveness of web content for a wide range of users.(2) A training center for children with hearing imparities is inaugurated in Tashkent city at the IT Park premises. Three groups of students, consisting of 24 people aged 13 to 19 years old, underwent training on a graphic design using Photoshop and Corel Draw; the basics of computer literacy and web technologies in two stages, including courses on Microsoft Office and Scratch language programming; and HTML and CSS. The Center is equipped by international standards and has all the necessary audio equipment for each child, taking into account his individual needs. Each teacher was individually trained in sound operation and tuning. Setting up the headphones, children don`t hear interference in the sound, which makes learning possible, accessible, and convenient. The classrooms were also equipped with laptops for each student and teacher, and interactive touch panels were installed for a visual demonstration of the teacher`s materials. The experts have created a special methodological base in Russian and Uzbek languages for the "graphic design" and "the basics of computer literacy and web technologies" courses. These manuals contain a detailed description of each topic, illustrations, and all the necessary terminology that students need.(3) Digital skills trainings for women from the Urgench region. 350 young women from the Urgench region are trained in digital literacy, coding, and graphic design. Digital skills obtained as a result of the training are to enable women and girls to get successfully employed, start their own business, or continue education: for this purpose, the students were acquainted with different online learning platforms. Depending on the level of their preparedness, the applicants were able to register for courses of 1st, 2nd, or 3rd levels: on computer literacy, programming, or graphic design accordingly. The course on computer literacy attracted the maximum number of participants. Courses on programming and graphic design were meant as a kind of basis for further self-tuition or professional education.(4) A digital skills center for women and youth in Tashkent city. Renovation of the center's facility (repurposing of an old PBX exchange) is completed. However, the delivery of the equipment is pending. Three training courses (materials, tutorials for educators) were developed. 50 women underwent training.(5) Awareness raising and advocacy campaign on girls and women enrolment into STEM education. The 10th Anniversary of Girls in ICT Day was celebrated in 2021. This year-long celebration took the form of 10 “moments” – events and activities focusing on the relevant stakeholders, topics, and initiatives that propel the mission of Girls in ICT. The 10 Moments series has been designed with three goals in mind: Build ​momentum and awareness about the importance of encouraging girls in STEM Engage key stakeholders and communities ​Provide an inclusive platform to discuss the best ways to encourage girls to pursue STEM careers
2022 Narrative: (1) Digital skills center for women and youth in Tashkent city is inaugurated in April 2022. 73 women completed in-depth training in frontend and backend development, Android programming and other ICT subjects.(2) Digital skills center for authists. Ongoing negotiations with the national partners.(3) Awareness raising and advocacy campaign on girls and women enrolment into STEM education.
2023 Narrative: ITU cоducted a regional study entitled 'Methodological bases for digital upskilliing of people with disabilities' aimedd at raising awareness on the matter of digital inclusion of people with disabilities, facilitating development of national programms/trainings for digital upskilling of people with disabilities, and promoting further establishment of a network of training centres for persons with disabilities The study contains:an overview of the existing educational programs on digital upskilling, relevant methods and assistive technologies;an anlysis of access to education for different categories of people with disabilities;an overview of public and private programmes to facilitate employment of persons with disabilities;list of professions available for employment of various categories of persons with digital disabilities;recommendations for decision-makers, educational institutions and private sector on digital upskilling of people with disabilities to ensure their proper digital citizenship and employment.9 countries of the CIS Region, including Uzbekistan, took part in the research.

Description: The project aims at laying the groundwork for the launching of the DIA Support Project through a research on relevant policies and good practices, stakeholder consultations and establishment of baselines for proper monitoring and evaluation of the development impact. The preparatory phase of the DIA Support Project is focused on informing the design of the larger intervention, which will be implemented over 3 years period of time and will strengthen national institutional capacity for developing human-rights based policies on the digitalization of public services, which should be of high quality, accessible and affordable by all citizens of Ukraine, including most vulnerable and marginalized. This project envisages gathering data, research, assessments, stakeholder consultations, including those with the international counterparts, and preparation of partnerships for full-scale roll-out of the larger project and collection of lessons learned, primarily from the UNDP network.

Description: The project aims at improving government institutions's knowledge and skills to design and implement policies to digitalize citizen-oriented services in line with HRBA principles, supporting development client-centred service packages built around life situations designed in a participatory manner, as well as enhancing Ukrainian women's and men's knowledge and skills related to different digital services.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNDP contributed to the transparency and accesibility of public services through the introduction of eight new pension, social and IDP e-services on the national Diia portal. In 2021, a total of 28,512 men and 28,662 women have  enjoyed digital, corruption-free, user-friendly public services compliant with Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) and accessible to persons with disabilities. Through public awareness campaing lauched to increase the citizens’ awareness of new electronic social and pension services in Diia, some 1.2 mln people were reached in Kyiv only (estimation based on billboards adverstising statistics). Through a wide advertising campaign in collaboration with Ministry of Digital Transformation and national postal operator Ukrposhta 3,000,000 leaflets on digital literacy opportunities provided via Diia.Digital Education portal were delivered to post-boxes of Ukrainians in 24 regions of Ukraine.
A total of 337 (216 women, 114 men) civil servants from the line ministries and national authority institution now have knowledge and skills on applying HRBA and gender mainstreaming in policy-making, as well as software development cycle, web accessibility and product management after participating in UNDP learning activities. Additional 7,576 persons have completed the interactive course ‘Public Policy and How It Is Shaped' developed by UNDP in partnership with Ministry of Digital Transformation, the Better Regulation Delivery Office in Ukraine and the National Agency of Ukraine on Civil Service. 97% of surveyed course attendants confirmed that their understanding of basic concepts of public policy formulation has increased substantially or partially.
Another area of work included UNDP expert support with policy and regulatory framework development with regards to e-services, upgrading of the state web accessibility standards and monitoring methodology.

Sub-Output: Young people, including women, are empowered with digital entrepreneurship skills and enabling environment for the digital economy is enhanced.
Contributing partners: Government of Uzbekistan, Russian Federation - UNDP Trust Fund for Development, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, Uzbekistan IT Park
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,1.2 By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: UNDP delivered efficient support in strengthening institutional capacities for developing digital economy  digital entrepreneurship ecosystem with focus on youth. For instance, one of the project results, “digitalpulse.uz” platform, launched  tested in 2022 by UNDP with participation of around 300 business entities, enables any MSMEs conduct self-assessment of the digital maturity level and obtain comprehensive package of recommendations on improving using of digital tools in business. This online self-assessment toolkit provides a targeted digital plan outlining the steps required to advance from one level of digital maturity to the next. It helps MSMEs’ managers adapt the firm’s strategy and understand which processes can be improved, which digital tools to adopt and which skills should be developed among the workforces. A website hosting the self-assessment is the most convenient and remotely accessible option for MSMEs’. The tool helps to swiftly investigate the different areas of operations and business functions common across sectors (e.g., production, marketing, human resources, accounting, CRM, and logistics) as well as those that are sector specific. Based on the outcome of the self-assessment, contact points and first recommendations for specific digital solutions and training is provided. The latter is a subset of generic steps included in relevant sector-specific digital plans.
2023 Narrative: UNDP worked effectively with the Gov partners to enhance the digital entrepreneurship and digital skills development ecosystem, through various initiatives.
2024 Narrative: The project implemented series of activities aimed at introducing private business development advisory platform which includes (1) providing consulting (mentorship, tracking, etc.) support with business development, (2) promotional opportunities (pitching and networking events, marketing support, etc.), and (3) financing solution – both private and public (mostly focused on venture capital – business angels, VC funds, etc.)

Implementation partners: Tech4Impact, Uzbekistan IT Park

Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.1 Output 3.1. By 2025, the capacities of national institutions and social partners are strengthened to design and implement effective and innovative Active Labour Market Policies, decent work and skills development programmes for the youth and adults (including NEET), women, informal workers, migrants, PWD to ensure inclusive and sustainable economic growth and reduced inequalities, including spacial and gender inequalities.
2021 Narrative: 188 girls across all regions of Uzbekistan were equipped with the STEM and social skills through the nanosatellite building programme, UniSat. Besides webinars on coding and engineering, a number of sessions with women in space and science area were delivered to motivate girls to continue their education and career in STEM sphere. In March during a hands-on workshop in Kazakhstan Al-Farabi university will build the nanosatellite and launch it on 11-12 April 2022.
2022 Narrative: 214 girls, including 70 girls with disabilities, from Karakalpakstan, Kashkadarya, Surkhandarya and Republican specialized schools in Tashkent were equipped with computer literacy, coding, graphic design and other digital skills. 120 girls from all regions of Uzbekistan are equipped with coding, engineering, 3D modelling and data analysis skills. Both programmes included components on life skills and gender social norms.
2023 Narrative: Jointly with the Ministry of Digital Technologies, UNICEF continues to equip girls with digital and STEM skills. CO integrated block coding and robotics into the Skills4Girls curriculum for girls without disabilities, and operation of call centers, graphic design and web programming and employability skills for girls with disabilities (49 girls).  UNICEF also leveraged resources of the local government to roll out the Skills4Gilrs in three districts of Kashkadarya region.  For now, 59 adolescents (30 girls and 29 boys) benefited. Through the nanosatellite building programme UniSat 2.0, UNICEF jointly with the CSO Tech4Impact and Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Innovation continued to empower and encourage girls to study and build their careers in STEM (199 girls), integrating more green skills and climate science into the programme curriculum. Two UniSat graduates were employed at Uzbek Cosmos Agency. One girl entered Colorado University, and another received an offer of full scholarship from Harvard and Princeton Universities, both with majors in Space Engineering.

Sub-Output: Improved knowledge about the readiness of SMEs in Uzbekistan for E-commerce, E-logistics, E-payment, and about the target markets and potential for Uzbekistani goods in selected markets through E-commerce channels; enhancing capacities of SMEs, in particular women-led companies, to enter digital markets and reinforce the E-commerce enabling sector (Ready4Trade project)
Implementation partners: Ministry of Investments and Foreign Trade of the Republic of Uzbekistan
SDG Targets: 8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.,17.11 Significantly increase the exports of developing countries, in particular with a view to doubling the least developed countries' share of global exports by 2020.
SDG Goals: 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
- Digital maturity assessment of 27 Uzbek SMEs conducted. 
- Online demand for the main goods produced by beneficiaries analysed; as a result, the most appropriate channels to enter regional and global markets were identified.
- Three of four modules of the foundational training on e-commerce completed (i.e. Module 1 “Market research and e-commerce strategy”, Module 2 “E-commerce content creation and optimization” and Module 3 “E-commerce platforms and online payment solutions”). The project first trained 8 national coaches, who, in their turn, delivered group trainings and individual advisory services to 39 SMEs (15 of which are women-led).
- eBay Central Asia hub launched in partnership with USAID, 8 Uzbek SMEs participate in it. SMEs are supported on opening an eBay store, resolving issues and each store is grouped under one regional eBay page.  SMEs received workshops on opening a store, developing niche positioning and pricing strategy, and selling techniques. Then each seller received up to 10 individual sessions with the international advisor.
- The project also helped Uzbek SMEs open their stores on Etsy and now assists these companies with optimizing their listings, enhancing visual appeal and promoting sales.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, the project completed its foundation training on e-commerce: 40 businesses and BSO representatives from 12 regions of Uzbekistan were trained on the entire e-commerce process, from identification of markets and customers, developing their value proposition, onboarding on online platforms, connecting with payments and logistics providers, and engaging in customer support and digital marketing. 22 companies completed the entire cycle of the 18-month training programme and collectively reported online sales for over 100 thousand USD since they joined the programme and opened or improved their online channels. SME beneficiaries from Uzbekistan also participated in five regional eLabs: eBay Central Asia hub (SMEs are supported on opening an eBay store, resolving issues and each store is grouped under one regional eBay page. SMEs received workshops on opening a store, developing niche positioning and pricing strategy, and selling techniques);Alibaba B2B marketplace;Etsy eLab;photo and video content creation;website creation and optimization.The project also created five video tutorials with subtitles in Uzbek on how to sell on eBay.
2023 Narrative: In February and March 2023, Uzbek beneficiaries participated in four webinars on the specifics of selling online in Europe. The webinars covered a range of topics, such as: product adaption for the European market; e-commerce strategy; social selling and importance of sustainability practices for successful sales to Europe. In 2023, Uzbek SMEs participated in regional eLabs and initiatives of the project on export management, social media, website optimization as well as those related to eBay, Alibaba, Foursource.NOVICA Artisan Empowerment hub selected Uzbek artisanal participants to join the platform, and already features 24 businesses from Uzbekistan. The project, in partnership with the Hunarmand association, organised an awareness raising event on e-commerce for artisans at the Kokand International Craft Festival on 21 September 2023.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the project, in partnership with the impact marketplace NOVICA, continued training and onboarding Central Asian artisans onto Artisans Connect (an online marketplace established earlier by the project) and other online platforms. Total sales across the region, including Uzbekistan, reached USD 180k.In 2024, the project continued to provide one-on-one support to eBay stores of Central Asian artisans under Central Asia Discoveries, helping boost sales. As a result, total sales of Central Asian artisans, including those from Uzbekistan, reached over USD 90k.In 2024, beneficiary SMEs and artisans in Uzbekistan continued to benefit from a 60% discount on DHL shipping rates, negotiated by the project.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030
Outcome: Outcome 3: By 2025, all people without discrimination benefit from a sustainable, inclusive and resilient economy in Georgia
Output: 3.2. Sustainable and inclusive agricultural and rural development, strengthened food systems and improved livelihoods.
Sub-Output: Improve Georgia's agriproduct export opportunities through the approximation of the agreements reached with the World Trade Organization (WTO) in sanitary and phytosanitary measures, elaboration of export development plan, and digitalization of export procedures
Description: To improve export opportunities for Georgia through better SPS and food safety systems under the DCFTA, approximated with EU standards
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Czech Development Agency, Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture of Georgia (MEPA)
SDG Targets: 2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.2 3.2. Sustainable and inclusive agricultural and rural development, strengthened food systems and improved livelihoods.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: In 2022, stakeholder coordination were conducted on various levels, and the agri-food laboratory infrastructure policy development process was initiated. Technical actions toward policy development were preceded by a meeting and discussion organized by MEPA. This initial meeting was attended by two deputies of MEPA, heads of SLA and NFA, several directors of MEPA departments, FAO and CzDA. FAO also started preparatory works and initiated discussions with Revenue Service concerning the model of issuance of export certificates. Export-related activities were discussed with the Head of Export Department of Enterprise Georgia of the Ministry of Economy that will allow to create a platform between exporters and exporter associations and the control and inspection bodies. On top of that, FAO identified two value chains (hazelnuts and wine) as priority value chains for training on EU export requirements. A needs assessment of wineries in terms of food safety requirements for EU export was implemented for four wineries, using a special questionnaire to obtain information about production and food safety risks. A full report will be produced once all information is processed. Also, the project did a first assessment (together with the EU4Business project) on the technical needs to improve the quality of grapes from an agronomic perspective, in the Tsinandali region. FAO organized several round tables with wineries in the Tsinandali/Telavi area to raise awareness in the process required to define and later implement the Protected Designation of Origin (PDO), bring more winemakers to the discussion and convince them of the necessity to work together to raise the general quality of a brand.
2023 Narrative: With the objective of reviewing the current model of export certificate issuance and proposing improvements, focusing on the digitalization of export procedures and suggesting recommendations for adopting NT TRACES, preparatory activities for a mission commenced in 2023. The main goal was to organize relevant training courses for the Revenue Service (RS) and National Food Agency (NFA) based on the training needs assessment conducted under UNSDCF sub-output 3.2.14, emphasizing official controls for import and export activities. To accomplish these objectives, FAO arranged a 2-week mission in March 2023. During this mission, the international consultants had discussions with representatives from RS and NFA on various aspects, including import controls for food of animal origin; specific elements of the export to the EU control system; analysis of EU border rejections of Georgian original food. International experts also visited an FBO exporting to the EU to evaluate their production process in accordance with EU general hygiene and specific requirements and a border control post, holding a separate meeting with RS to further clarify the analysis of the situation with TRACE NT and the e-certification system in Georgia. Following the meetings, training sessions, centering on official border controls, with a specific emphasis on key requirements related to animal health and regulations for products of animal origin were conducted. The achievements of this activity are reported under UNSDCF sub-output 3.2.14. A comprehensive report encompassing the review of key findings and suggested recommendations for improvement of export procedures was submitted after the completion of the mission. Consultations on the establishment of the Export Policy Facilitation Platform between exporters and exporters associations and control and inspection bodies are ongoing and expected to formalize the process in 2024.
2024 Narrative: A qualitative survey was conducted among agricultural product associations and export professionals to identify key barriers to market access, leading to enhanced trade facilitation efforts. A TRACES NT workshop was attended by 50 technical staff from NFA and Revenue Services, alongside 15 private sector representatives, to streamline export procedures. Additionally, a coordination meeting among agri-food laboratories was held to assess sectoral needs and improve national laboratory capacities for export compliance.

Plan name: Turkmenistan UNSDCF 2021 - 2025
Strategic priority: Priority B. Inclusive, green, and sustainable economic growth
Outcome: Outcome 3.  By 2025, there is effective design and implementation of disaster risk reduction and climate adaptation and mitigation measures, enabling a more rational use of resources, increased resilience, and a ‘green’ economy transition
Output: Output 3.3. Government institutions, private sector, and civil society, trade unions have increased capacities to apply innovations, digital technology and green solutions contributing to efficient use of energy, water, land and other natural resources, renewable energy and development of sustainable cities and green economy with active participation of women, children and vulnerable groups of population
Sub-Output: Developing digital solutions for sustainable pasture management
Description: The planned outcome of the project "Developing digital solutions for sustainable pasture management" is to do the inventory of pastures and develop science-based guidelines for livestock keepers (pasture users) of the Dashoguz region on sustainable use of pastures. Animal husbandry is a key branch of agriculture in the Dashoguz region, which is the geographic emphasis of this project.
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Implementation partners: Turkmenistan Ministry of Agriculture
SDG Targets: 2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: Inception mission was conducted by international and national consultants to Ashgabat, Dashoguz, Turkmenistan between 19-25 November 2023.The below activities were performed.- The data and documents required for desk work were listed in collaboration with the international expert team members,- Site selection criteria for the pilot areas were listed in close cooperation with the international expert team members,- Joint activities related with GCP/SEC/014/TUR-Improving Efficiency of Small Ruminants Production for Reduction of the GHG Emission Intensity Project and TCP/TUK/3903/C1 (733482)- Developing Digital Solutions for Sustainable Pasture Management Project, which are implementing in Turkmenistan were listed to create synergy and to increase multiplier effects of both projects,- Detail Mission Program to joint consultancy meetings with key government stakeholders and to conduct field visits and field observations to decide on project pilot plot and demonstration site was prepared in close cooperation with project team.
2024 Narrative: Under the project "TCPF: Developing Digital Solutions for Sustainable Pasture Management," significant progress has been made. National and international experts have actively exchanged information and gathered the necessary data for effective pasture management. National experts have conducted several missions to the pilot area, sharing valuable insights and information from each mission with their international counterparts.Additionally, a Project Task Force meeting was organized, where the activities to be carried out under the project were thoroughly discussed. This collaborative effort has ensured that all stakeholders are aligned and well-informed, paving the way for the successful implementation of sustainable pasture management solutions.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030

Output: 3.3. Increased productive employment, decent work, skills development and effective national social protection for all
Sub-Output: Fostering digital innovation sector and artificial intelligence solutions by proving evidence-based country-specific recommendations following a national digital innovation profile, as well as raising awareness by engaging all stakeholders through a series of webinars and holding  a national launching event of the assessment.
Description: Fostering digital innovation and artificial intelligence solutions by providing recommendations through a national digital innovation profile and related stakeholder dialogue
Implementation partners: Ministry of Economy and Sustainable Development of Georgia
SDG Targets: 8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.3 3.3. Increased productive employment, decent work, skills development and effective national social protection for all
2021 Narrative:
In 2021, the ITU started proving assistance to Georgia in building an ICT-centric innovation ecosystem. This translated into the elaboration of a Digital Innovation Profile for Georgia in collaboration with UNESCO, including desktop research, the organization of national consultations, engagement of relevant stakeholders, processing a series of interviews, which led to providing a set of country-specific recommendations to foster digital innovation and artificial intelligence sectors of the country. The Slovenia International Research Centre On Artificial Intelligence seconded experts to support the component of investigation focusing on AI. 

A series of co-creation workshops were held on 18-19 May and 3 June 2021 with Georgian stakeholders on recommendations and the assessment of the innovation ecosystem in the country.

The Digital Innovation Profile is expected to be launched in 2022, during a national launching event. In addition, assistance may be provided to ensure the follow-up to the Digital Innovation Profile with the elaboration of the national strategy on emerging technologies, including AI.

2021 Narrative:
The ITU has elaborated a Digital Development Country Profile for Georgia which seeks
to equip the UNCT, other decision-makers at the national level, and international stakeholders with 
an overview of the various components of digital development at the country level. Such country profile benefited inputs/ review from FAO and UNESCO Georgia country offices. The Digital Development Country Profile series also aims to provide a comparative analysis for priority 
countries of the European region, namely Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Moldova, 
Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, and Ukraine.

This country profile will lay the basis for evidence-based discussions at the national level as well as potential assistance to be provided in 2022.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP3_Enhanced shared prosperity in a sustainable economy
Outcome: OC3_By 2027, all people of Moldova, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, competitive and sustainable economic development and equal access to decent work and productive employment
Output: OU 3.4_People of Moldova, in particular those left behind, have improved access to adequate protection and safe working conditions, knowledge, in-demand skills and resources to foster employability, competitiveness and entrepreneurship culture
Sub-Output: Digital Literacy Assessment of Adult Population in Moldova
Description: The ITU-ILO project “Inclusive and productive employment in Moldova”, will be assessing the digital literacy of the adult population, targeting adults aged 45+ in rural areas, and focusing on women and disadvantaged groups. The project will aim to assess digital literacy levels among adults, identifying skill gaps that affect employment, with the goal to improve employability by addressing these gaps and providing insights into necessary technological skills.
Implementation partners: International Telecommunication Union
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The assessment will place a special focus on women and will aim to have an equal gender balance.
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.2 OU 3.2_Regulatory framework and institutions promote economic empowerment of women and their equal access to decent work, 3.4 OU 3.4_People of Moldova, in particular those left behind, have improved access to adequate protection and safe working conditions, knowledge, in-demand skills and resources to foster employability, competitiveness and entrepreneurship culture, 3.1 OU 3.1_Policy and institutional frameworks create an empowering environment for inclusive and sustainable economic development that promotes creation of productive and decent work
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2025 Narrative: In alignment with national policy documents, such as ‘Moldova Europeană 2030’ and the ‘Educația 2030’ program, there is a strong emphasis on developing an accessible, flexible, and relevant system for continuous adult education. This focus includes enhancing digital competencies and leveraging information technologies to improve digital literacy across various adult groups. In response to a request from the Ministry of Education and Research in 2021, the International Labour Organization (ILO) is supporting the promotion of digital literacy for adults (45-65) in rural areas, with a particular focus on low-skilled / low-educated populations, women and disadvantaged groups.The ILO project proposes a comprehensive assessment of digital literacy among the above-mentioned segments of the adult population in Moldova. The assessment will focus on digital skills, evaluating current competencies and identifying technological skill gaps that impact employment and employability of low-skilled and disadvantaged adults. The primary objective is to gauge digital skills in rural areas, identify gaps, and provide insights into technological skills necessary for improving employability for unemployed and disadvantaged populations.To effectively carry out this assessment and leverage the expertise required, the ILO signed a UN-to-UN agreement with the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), (hereinafter ‘Implementing Partner’). This partnership will ensure access to ITU's specialized knowledge and resources in digital skills assessment, enhancing the quality and impact of the evaluation.The ITU will be responsible for designing the methodology for the assessment, conducting the assessment, and drafting a report, including recommendations. The assessment will serve as a catalyst for creating and implementing training programs that address skills needed for everyday activities, using digital government services, and improving employability, with a particular focus on gender-related needs and challenges.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote inclusive and gender transformative approaches to climate action, disaster risk management and environmental protection to conserve natural resources and leverage ecosystem benefits for sustainable human development (CLIMATE, ENERGY, DRM AND BIODIVERSITY)
Outcome: By 2027, the Kyrgyz Republic has started the transition to low-carbon development and risk-informed climate resilience, contributing to people’s fair and equitable access to ecosystem benefits and to empowerment of vulnerable communities in the governance of natural resources and disaster prevention
Output: Capacity of disaster management systems is strengthened, and community resilience to multiple shocks is increased at all levels through enhanced participation of women in DRR planning, as well as effective investments, policies, mechanisms, and tools
Sub-Output: Enhanced disaster risk management, prevention and and preparedness systems operationalized and implemented at all government levels (gender and health considerations, digital and innovative methods for forecasting of threats and hazards) has context menu
Description: Enhanced disaster risk management, prevention and preparedness systems in healthcare : Joint External Evaluation process of IHR core capacities in the country; costing of the National Action Plan for Health Security based on the results of the Joint external evaluation; utilization of One health approach.
Contributing partners: Core Funding, United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,3.9 By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: WHO assisted national counterparts in conducting the Joint External Evaluation process of IHR core capacities in the country and facilitated the development and costing of the National Action Plan for Health Security based on the results of the Joint external evaluation, state party annual reporting, strategic tool for assessing the risks, and other IHR monitoring and evaluation framework tools and utilizing whole-of-government and One health approach. WHO provided assistance in further development of digital health tools, such as laboratory information management system, epidemiological early warning digital platform, register of underlying conditions, assigned population system and national indicators platform to ensure integrated COVID-19 response and continuation of essential health services.
2024 Narrative: WHO CO continues to strengthen the capacity of the digital platform - iEpid  iLab as part of the work on the National Action Plan for Health Security (2024-2030). In 2024, the work was done to promote the Collaborative Zoonotic Disease Surveillance (through the implementation of the One Health approach). The essence of the approach is the exchange of emergency notifications in digital platform between MoH and Vet Services under MWRAPI. Currently, these platforms are not connected and exist separately, therefore, understudy platforms have been developed for the Vet. Service, which will enable the implementation of this approach next year. Virtual maps of anthrax burial sites in the country have also been developed for instant access of public health workers, and reporting forms have been created to reduce the time required for completion.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Outcome: By 2027, the Kyrgyz Republic has started the transition to low-carbon development and risk-informed climate resilience, contributing to people’s fair and equitable access to ecosystem benefits and to empowerment of vulnerable communities in the governance of natural resources and disaster prevention
