Sub-Output: Disaster risk management systems enhanced through innovative digital and inclusive methods for assessment, profiling, mapping and monitoring disaster and climate risks as well as integration of Anticipatory Actions in local DRM plans
Contributing partners: Government of Switzerland, The Green Climate Fund
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Emergency Situations, Kyrgyz Ministry of Natural Resources, Ecology and Technical Supervision
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,11.5 By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.,11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.,13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 2 Zero Hunger, 10 Reduced Inequalities, 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities, 13 Climate Action
Geography: Jumgal, Naryn, Jalal-Abad, Aravan, Nookat, Batken (city), Batken, Aksy, Batken, Kyrgyzstan, Kadamjai, Sulukta (city), Toktogul, Jalal-Abad (city), Suzak, Tash-Kumir (city), Osh, Naryn, Naryn (city), Mailuu-Suu (city), Kyzyl-Kia (city), Ak-Tala, Nooken, Leilek, Kara-Kul (city)
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: Innovative digital and inclusive methods for assessment, profiling, mapping and monitoring disaster and climate risks consider gender perspectives. The activity ensures the equal participation of women and men during development of climate risk profiling (during which gender analysis conducted), community adaptation planning and disaster preparedness exercises.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: WFP successfully conducted a pilot for localized DRR/climate profiles in Aravan district, elaborating the new localized methodology for replication in other target areas. These profiles are crucial for tailoring adaptation measures to address specific community needs, offering insight into current and future DRR/climate-related risks on livelihoods and food security. The risk profiling involves mapping and identifying risk zones for key livelihoods, raising public and government awareness, ensuring evidence-based approach to supporting communities in adapting to climate change.
2024 Narrative: WFP developed climate risk profiles for eight districts in Batken, Jalal-Abad, Naryn, and Osh provinces, supporting local governments in creating risk-informed socio-economic development plans for 2025. By utilizing these risk profiles, local governments can help farmers adapt their cropping practices to climate impacts, thereby reducing their vulnerability to climate hazards and enhancing the resilience of rural communities. WFP also piloted the internationally recognized disaster risk assessment model, "INFORM", in Suzak district. The potential scale-up of this model to other areas aims to strengthen national capacities for disaster risk management.WFP supported piloting Anticipatory Actions designed to protect the livelihoods of vulnerable pastoralists before a climate risk materializes, based on climate forecasts. Triggered by a prolonged cold winter and heavy snowfall in the high mountain pastures of two districts in Naryn Province, 232 tons of prepositioned fodder were distributed by district authorities to 3,561 pastoralists. The provided fodder helped these pastoralists prevent mass livestock deaths and improve their ability to sustain livestock during harsh winter conditions. A revolving mechanism was established to replenish the distributed fodder in the warehouses, ensuring preparedness for the 2024-2025 winter season. WFP also continued to integrate the digital climate hazard monitoring system - Platform for Real-time Impact and Situation Monitoring (PRISM) - into the national disaster risk monitoring system, facilitating the government's strategic shift from recovery and response to prevention and mitigation of disaster risks. The digital system has been deployed on the server of the Ministry of Emergency Situations.WFP has been developing an Atlas of Mudflow Risk to identify the prevalence and vulnerability of the country's territories to mudflows in various areas. This Atlas can serve as the basis for the Ministry’s online platform for mudflow monitoring and forecasting within its disaster risk management system. With this solution, the Ministry, local authorities, and communities will be able to more effectively mitigate, prepare for, and respond to mudflows.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2: Peace - Effective Institutions, Human Rights and Gender Equality
Outcome: Outcome 2.2: By 2025, state institutions at all levels effectively design and implement gender-sensitive, human rights and evidence-based public policies and provide quality services in an inclusive, transparent and accountable manner.
Output: Output 2.2.2: Strengthened capacities of government authorities and CSOs for effective, efficient, timely and inclusive provision of specialized social services with a focus on the most vulnerable groups, including the context of the Covid-19 pandemic
Sub-Output: Capacity Development of Public Servants for Advancing Digital Transformation and Digital Governance.
Description:
This project covers twelve countries situated in three geographical regions, i.e., in the Caucasus, and in Asia and the Pacific, which have taken some steps towards the digitalisation of their government operations and processes and for the delivery of public services to business and citizens, however in a varying degree. Moreover, most of them have also embraced the notion of digital transformation and of digital governance in their development strategies, although much still needs to be done towards their goal for digital transformation; incorporating the latest digital technologies, i.e., evidence-based policy formulation and implementation by harnessing abundant “big data”, or for the provision of proactive, efficient, and effective public services digitally.
Hence, this project – fully recognising the value of digital transformation and of digital governance – aims at further developing the capacities of public servants at different levels of government by transferring knowledge and experience enabling them to implement initiatives that will advance digital transformation and digital governance in their countries. It is expected that such knowledge and experience sharing will assist the participating countries to further develop policies initiatives that will allow them to establish data-driven public sectors for evidence-based policy making and implementation, and to introduce digital open governments that are proactive and user-driven resulting to efficient and effective public service provision and an increase of trust in government. Ultimately, utilising digitalisation for shaping public governance outcomes will be beneficial for their citizens.
Contributing partners: Government of the Republic of Korea
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, resilient, and sustainable economic development with improved productive capacities, skills and equal opportunities for sustainable and decent jobs, livelihoods, and businesses.
Output: Output 3.1.3: Increased capacities of MMSEs and enterpenuers to create a conducive environment, to better integrate into the value chains, develop innovative approaches for enterpeneurial activities, and create decent job opportunities
Sub-Output: Ready4Trade Central Asia: Improve knowledge about the readiness of SMEs in Kazakhstan for E-commerce, E-logistics, E-payment, and about the target markets and potential for Kazakhstani goods in selected markets through E-commerce channels; enhance capacities of SMEs, in particular women-led companies, to enter digital markets and reinforce the e-commerce enabling sector; improve SMEs capacities to comply with cross-border requirements, through the Export Management Coaching Initiative and the Cross-Border Management Curriculum
Implementation partners: QazTrade Center for Policy Development JSC
SDG Targets: 8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Improving SMEs' capacities to comply with cross-border requirements:
- A Virtual Learning Space for the Cross-Border Management Curriculum (a series of courses targeting local exporters) was established and adapted for the institutional partner QazTrade.
- Four courses of the Cross-Border Management Curriculum were developed and uploaded on the Platform. The courses cover the following topics: 1) Rules of Trade; 2) Export Process; 3) EU Market Requirements; 4) Quality and Conformity Standards.  
- Eight national coaches were trained as part of the Export Management Coaching Initiative (EMCI).
- In total, 44 tailored individual coaching missions were delivered for SMEs (incl. 23 women-owned or managed SMEs)  in partnership with QazTrade as part of the EMCI.
- The EMCI mid-term event was held in Almaty with the participation of SMEs, national coaches, QazTrade, EU, USAID and other relevant stakeholders. The event presented the methodology of the EMCI to the key local partners, reported on the lessons learnt from the delivery of coaching missions to SMEs in Kazakhstan since January 2021. The mid-term event also enabled beneficiary SMEs to reflect on lessons learnt from the coaching services by sharing their experience and interacting with national coaches, partners, and other participating SMEs. 
- The final wrap-up event is going to be held in Q1 2021.

Supporting SMEs’ engagement in e-commerce:
- Digital maturity assessment of 40 Kazakh SMEs was conducted.
- Online demand for the main goods produced by beneficiaries was analysed; as a result, the most appropriate channels to enter regional and global markets were identified.
- Three of four modules of the foundational training on e-commerce were completed (i.e. Module 1 “Market research and e-commerce strategy”, Module 2 “E-commerce content creation and optimization” and Module 3 “E-commerce platforms and online payment solutions”). ITC first trained 8 national coaches, who, in their turn, delivered group trainings and individual advisory services to 39 SMEs (26 of which are women-led).
- eBay Central Asia hub launched in partnership with USAID, 4 Kazakh SMEs participate in it. SMEs are supported on opening an eBay store, resolving issues and each store is grouped under one regional eBay page. SMEs received workshops on opening a store, developing niche positioning and pricing strategy, and selling techniques. Then each seller received up to 10 individual sessions with the international advisor.
Q3 Report:
•	40 SMEs have been supported through group training and individual coaching on e-commerce (including support with improving the digital identity of SMEs as well as their online presence in leading marketplaces, such as eBay). Achieved online sales already exceeded USD 500,000.
•	44 SMEs benefitted from five-day individual on-the-job coaching sessions on export management.
•	As part of Cross-Border Management Curriculum, SMEs are being trained on various topics related to international trade. Trainings are available both online (though the online Virtual Learning Space (VLS) platform – launched on 19 September 2022 in Astana) and in person.
2022 Narrative: Improving SMEs' capacities to comply with cross-border requirements:On 19 September 2022, the project officially launched the Cross-Border Trade Management Curriculum in Kazakhstan. As part of the initiative, the Action also launched a Virtual Learning Space (VLS) platform for Kazakhstan – QazTrade Academy. More than 50 private and public sectors’ representatives participated in the launch event covered by national media.In 2022, the total of eight two-day and four-day instructor-led workshops took place in the various regions of Kazakhstan, including two workshops in Astana, and one each in Almaty, Uralsk, Aktobe, Taraz, Kyzylorda, Karaganda, Kostanay, with over 330 total participants, including 160+ women.The Curriculum currently has five modules, covering the following topics: The Rules of International Trade, Export Process, Exporting to EU, Quality and Conformity, and Road Transit Routes.Supporting SMEs’ engagement in e-commerce:In 2022, the project completed its foundation training on e-commerce: 40 businesses were trained on the entire e-commerce process, from identification of markets and customers, developing their value proposition, onboarding on online platforms, connecting with payments and logistics providers, and engaging in customer support and digital marketing.  These 40 businesses, 25 of which are women-led, represent 9 regions of Kazakhstan. SMEs represent textile and garments and artisanal sectors. 30 of the participating companies completed the entire cycle of 18 months training program and collectively reported online sales for around 500 thousand USD since they joined the program and opened or improved their online channels. SME beneficiaries from Kazakhstan also participated in three eLabs: eBay Central Asia hub (SMEs are supported on opening an eBay store, resolving issues and each store is grouped under one regional eBay page. SMEs received workshops on opening a store, developing niche positioning and pricing strategy, and selling techniques);photo and video content creation;website creation and optimization.The project also created five video tutorials with subtitles in Kazakh on how to sell on eBay.
2024 Narrative: Cross-Border Management Curriculum initiative:In February 2024, the project launched a regional contest called the “Marathon of Knowledge” to incentivize the institutional partners of the Curriculum initiative to collaborate with local universities, training centres and business associations to further promote the online courses of the Curriculum among SMEs in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. Thus, QazTrade, in collaboration with KazakhExport and the DAMU Entrepreneurship Development Fund, conducted a series of marathons in various regions of Kazakhstan. In Q1 2024, four successful marathons were conducted in Astana, Almaty, Shymkent, and Akmola, with around 100 participants completing the online courses on the QazTrade Academy platform.Two national courses, “Kazakhstan: the Role of Customs and Exchange Controls” and “Kazakhstan: Customs Inspections and Technical Regulations”, were developed by the Action and launched on the QazTrade Academy platform.Since the launch of the Curriculum initiative in Kazakhstan, over 3,500 users have successfully completed Curriculum courses online or offline and earned certifications.E-commerce support to SMEs:In 2024, the project, in partnership with the impact marketplace NOVICA, continued training and onboarding Central Asian artisans onto Artisans Connect (an online marketplace established earlier by the project) and other online platforms. Total sales across the region reached USD 180k.In 2024, the project continued to provide one-on-one support to eBay stores of Central Asian artisans under Central Asia Discoveries, helping boost sales. As a result, total sales of Central Asian artisans reached over USD 90k.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, resilient, and sustainable economic development with improved productive capacities, skills and equal opportunities for sustainable and decent jobs, livelihoods, and businesses.
Output: Output 3.1.2: Enhanced capacities of key stakeholders at national and sub-national levels on labour force resilience and equal skills development opportunities
Sub-Output: Strengthened capacities of national institutions and educational stakeholders to design and implement digital skills development programmes for women and girls, PWD to ensure inclusive participation in the digital development
Description: The sub-out aimes at the delivering a digital upskilling activities aimed at awareness and capacity building on gender digital divide and digital inclusion of people of disabilities
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Digital Development, Innovations and Aerospace Industry
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: 1) A series of training on cyber hygiene (child online safety) and digital skills was conducted for 5th–8th-grade students (299 students in total) from three public schools in Kostanau.2) A hackathon "Business Hack" was conducted in partnership with "SaryarkaAutoProm", "Kostanau Agromechanical Plant" and a network of family cafes "Muslima", which provided the participants with real business cases. 77 persons aged 16+ participated in the hackathon: 12 IT professionals aged 16-26 (2 females) and 14 start-ups led by persons aged 16-25 (2 female leaders).3) Regional baseline assessment on digital accessibility (in Russian with executive summary in English) is conducted and published (https://www.itu.int/pub/D-PHCB-ICT_ACCESS_CIS.01-2021); online training courses on web-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/web-accessibility-cornerstone-digital-societyon-line-self-paced-training-0) and ICT-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/ict-accessibility-key-inclusive-communication-line-self-paced-training) are translated into Russian.4) In 2021 ITU finalized procurement and delivery of the equipment necessary to create a smart education ecosystem in KInEU University (Kostanay). The core network of the KInEU university was upgraded to ensure distribution of high-speed internet withing the university campus, a platform for organizing distance learning, videoconferencing, and lP-telephony.
2022 Narrative: 1) Smart education ecosystem in Kostanay. In 2022, in consultation with akimats of Kostanay city and the Kostanay region, 6 educational institutions were selected to be connected to the university’s network (KInEU became an Internet-hub for local community) with 600 users in total: Chaikovski Secondary School (Zhitikara District), Zhambyl Secondary School (Kostanay District), Amankaragai Secondary School named after N.Ostrovski (Auliekol District), Amankaragai Secondary School No.2 (Auliekol District), Corporate University of LLP “Saryarka AvtoProm”, hostel of the “KInEU College of Entrepreneurship”. All facilities were connected at the speed of at 10 Mbps – global absolute minimum recommended by Giga.  Each facility is fully covered by a wireless network and is able to communicate with the university to solve possible technical problems with the network and equipment. Objects are provided with access data to manage their local websites with content placement and administration rights. The smart education ecosystem has improved the quality of education in the connected institutions and allows for context-dependent global learning in the digital age to meet the needs of work and life in the 21st century. Apart from this, 32 lecturers of the KInEU were trained in digital literacy and the use of ICT in the educational process. This course was developed in order to upgrade digital skills of lecturers so that they will be able to efficiently and creatively teach students using the full capacity of equipment purchased to create smart education ecosystem.2) The Kostanay Engineering and Economics University named after M.Dulatov with ITU support conducted two trainings to enhance digital and entrepreneurial skills of youth. In February 2022 93 youth representatives (30% women), including start-up leads and youth entrepreneurs took part in a master class for start-up beginners in ICT sphere. The trainees gained knowledge on developing a business model, launching of a start-up with limited seed money, promotion of start-up through CRM system, and on the use of RFID technologies for digital identification and assets control. In July 2022 16 students from 3 higher education institutions took part in the World Skills-2022 Regional Championship in Prototyping. The programm included trainings on 3D printer calibration, performing measurements and drawing sketches , creating and developing a 3D model of the product in a CAD environment and creating a model-prototype.
2023 Narrative: To raise awareness on the matter of digital inclusion of people with disabilities, to facilitate development of national programms/trainings for digital upskilling of people with disabilities, and to promote further establishment of a network of training centres for persons with disabilities ITU cоducted a regional study entitled 'Methodological bases for digital upskilliing of people with disabilities'. The study contains:an overview of the existing educational programs on digital upskilling, relevant methods and assistive technologies;an anlysis of access to education for different categories of people with disabilities;an overview of public and private programmes to facilitate employment of persons with disabilities;list of professions available for employment of various categories of persons with disabilities;recommendations for decision-makers, educational institutions and private sector on digital upskilling of people with disabilities to ensure their proper digital citizenship and employment.9 countries of the CIS Region, including Kazakhstan, took part in the research.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2 - Sustainable, inclusive and equitable economic growth
Outcome: Outcome 2.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, have access to enhanced livelihood opportunities, decent work and productive employment, generated by sustainable, inclusive and equitable economic growth
Output: (2022) 2.2 People from vulnerable groups (including women, youth, people from special status regions) have relevant skills and knowledge and improved access to resources and sustainable jobs and livelihoods
Sub-Output: Provide technical knowledge, support and incentives to  women from marginalized groups to access decent work, social protection and sustainable livelihoods, including digital skills and financial literacy
Description:
Provide technical knowledge, support and incentives to  women from marginalized groups to access decent work, social protection and sustainable livelihoods, including digital skills and financial literacy
Partners: CSOs -  XY Partners, Sweet Mary Ltd.

2 events organised in partnership with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration of the Republic of Moldova (economic diplomacy department), UN Women Moldova organized 2 dedicated to promoting and identifying new markets for women producers and women entrepreneurs that got supported within the business development and capacity building programmes of UN Women. 

Participation of women producers to 4 international promotion events was ensured (Riga Food 2022, Christmas Charity Bazar for Embassy of Republic of Moldova to Latvia (Riga), Embassy of Republic of Moldova to Austria (Vienna) and Permanent Mission of Republic of Moldova to UN Office and other international organizations in Geneva (Switzerland). The samples of local products were presented and sold at the Christmas Bazar and the funds donated for charity.
30 women led start-ups, including 16 from social - vulnerable groups, were selected and participated in the 4th Women Entrepreneurship Pre-acceleration Programme. An online pitching session was organized at the end of the programme.
The first acceleration programme was organized for women and girls, who graduated one of the four pre-acceleration programs previously organized by UN Women and have already a running business with sales that needed to be scaled up. The accelerator program Women Entrepreneurship was organized as an intensive 3 months business development program designed to support women led start-ups in increasing their revenues and expanding on external markets.
At the end of the programme 8 women entrepreneurs pitched their ideas within Demo day in front of panel of potential investors.
10 women led start-ups, graduates of the first 4 pre-acceleration programmes, were granted a 40,000 MDL voucher for marketing and legal expenses with a personal contribution of 5% of the voucher amount. 
About 100 women producers enhanced their knowledge and skills in the 3 main areas as promotion and social media, access to finance and legal counselling and support. 10 capacity building sessions delivered on the topics identified as necessary through the needs assessment research: Access to affordable financial sources, Legal issues regarding national and international certification and standardization; Access to local and international markets; Social media promotion and online marketing.
2 Voucher Support Programmes launched and delivered with a total budget of 1, 5 million MDL, through which 23 women were financed to acquire services and equipment necessary to directly support development of women local producers’ businesses. 
3 mentoring sessions have been offered to beneficiaries at the request in the following areas: Accounting, in particular with focus on VAT; Sales and customers; Effective promotion and communication via social networks.
1 business orientation session organized with the participation of an international expert and entrepreneurship professor with focus on process of business development especially expansion into international markets.
Implementation partners: Moldova, Sweet Mary ltd

Description:
General theme: Supporting digitalization and innovative solutions to close the digital divide
Outcome 3: Economic growth
Output 4.1: People, including marginalised and vulnerable groups, are empowered to build productive capacities and benefit from community development in rural and urban areas ensuring sustainable livelihoods and decent jobs
Existing programme: Wholegrain Wheat Value Chain Project/Berd project /Potato Value Chain Project
Contributing partners: British Embassy, Core Funding, UN Trust Fund for Human Security, WFP 2030 Fund
Implementation partners: United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, resources.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way

2021 Narrative: Lower production costs mean that products can be sold for lower prices, making them competitive in the market. In 2021, WFP made investments in modern machinery, including solar stations that off-set electricity costs and give businesses and advantage in the market in eight SMEs in Tavush. This approach increased the profitability and productivity of targeted actors along the food value chain and will be scaled up in 2022.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Sub-Output: Support to MoE to implement the Strategy for Digitalization of Education (2022 - 2027), with special focus on digital platform deployment, digital content development, and capacity building for teachers and students, particularly most vulnerable ones

Contributing partners: European Union, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, United Nations Children's Fund

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: With support of UNICEF, the Ministry of Education is implementing a comprehensive set of interventions aimed at creating functional digital eco-systems at the school level, as well as at consolidating the use of the Digital School Platform among all beneficiaries, i.e., teachers, students, and parents. The current initiative includes several key interventions: a massive capacity building component, support visits / information sessions for 40 schools, piloting of the cooperation between two schools based on the Digital School Concept, as well as development of additional digital content for teachers, students, and parents. The number of users of the MoESI Digital School Platform increased by 33 per cent compared to the previous year, with the platform being enriched by additional digital content for students, teachers and parents.  As one of the several countries participating in the Regional Office-led project “A Voice for Every Child”, Montenegro was the recipient of the international 2024 Zero Award for implementing the C-board app for children with severe communication difficulties.
2024 Narrative: The national Digital School Platform (based on the Learning Passport) has 27,918 active users, with 53 new courses developed in 2024. Furthermore, UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education, Science and Innovation to establish EdTech hubs and a related programme across 12 primary and secondary schools in the north of the country, reaching 6,000 pupils. Over 500 children were supported to develop digital, critical thinking and problem-solving skills in 12 primary schools, as well as an additional 1,120 through UNICEF-supported workshops at the national Days of Science Festival.

2021 Narrative:
The intervention of the ILO focused on the reform of the Employment Agency of Montenegro. 
ILO conducted a Functional Assessment of the EAM, which served as a basis for designing the intervention. The intervention resulted in new internal organizational Act of the EAM, 66 new internal procedures, 2 new Active labour market procedures (ALMP) designed and piloted, and a diversified set of trainings for the staff of the EAM with special focus on the monitoring and evaluation.
3 online modules developed (registration of unemployed, of employers and one special module for persons with disabilities)

MOR je izvršio Funkcionalnu procjenu ZZZCG, koja je poslužila kao osnova za osmišljavanje intervencije. Intervencija je rezultirala novim aktom o unutrašnjoj organizaciji Zavoda, 66 novih internih procedura, 2 nove Aktivne mjere tržišta rada dizajnirane i pilotirane, te raznovrsnim setom obuka za osoblje Zavoda sa posebnim fokusom na praćenje i evaluaciju .
Razvijena 3 online modula (registracija nezaposlenih, poslodavaca i jedan poseban modul za osobe sa invaliditetom)

2021 Narrative:
Following the adoption of the internal procedures, the ILO intervention focused  on 
translation of procedures into digital forms as a step towards in decreasing the workload for the caseworkers, enabling them to dedicate more time to clients. 

Nakon usvajanja internih procedura, intervencija MOR-a se fokusira na
prevođenje procedura u digitalne forme kao korak ka smanjenju obima posla za radnike na predmetima, omogućavajući im da posvete više vremena klijentima.
2022 Narrative: The ILO focused on the supporting Ministry and EAM in preparing for tender procedure for digitalisation of the EAM based on the previously delivered specification of hardware and software. The ILO has conducted three seminars with EAM staff to present the practical approach to identify ex ante the elements that constitute a quality offer of employment when a Youth Guarantee offer is made. Based on existing policy frameworks and research on employment quality this approach will serve as a tool to measure the quality of services and programmes provided to unemployed clients by a Public Employment Service. With the assistance of technical ILO expert EAM was presented with the recommendations for improvement of quality of reporting based on the Performance monitoring analysis of ALMPs.The EAM discontinued employers’ survey for 3 years. The ILO presented them the technical assistance they can expect in this regard. Presentation of the time-use survey and Functional assessment to the new management has been conducted. This helped ILO raise awareness to the part of the management to the existing situation and the administrative tasks that could be automatized and help save time to the employees. The analysis of the procurement procedures has been conducted and results shared with the Ministry.

Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Interior
SDG Targets: 5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

2023 Narrative: UNDP-	The comparative gap analysis is being prepared and will detail the legislative reforms necessary for improvement of the approach to combatting SGBV in the digital sphere. Representatives of the MoI and prosecutors were capacitated through specialized trainings and consultative workshops tackling digital sex crime and increase gender sensitization of employees dealing with investigations of digital sex crimes. Visibility events (forum theatre) were organized as part of the 16 days of activism against gender-based violence campaign.
2024 Narrative: UNDP- The Comprehensive Legislative Analysis on Technology Facilitated Gender -based Violence (TF-GBV) was finalized in an inclusive collaborative process with all relevant stakeholders, and was promoted at a high-level event that served to increased awareness on the topic. A Study visit was organized to the Republic of Korea for 9 Ministry of Interior representatives, in order to strengthen the investigative and preventive capacities. A tailor-made training curriculum was developed for police officers, public prosecutors and service providers, and was presented both as an in-person training for over 30 participants, as well as developed as an e-learning course that is installed on the MoI e-learning platform. Police officers attended a specialized Training of Trainers organized by the Korean National Police Agency. A social media awareness-raising campaign was organized in North Macedonia, focusing on youth. Thousands of young people engaged with the campaign through various social media channels and in-person events aimed at strengthening their capacities for identifying, preventing and reporting cases of TF-GBV. The goals achieved are in line with the Seoul Policy Center’s SDG Partnership Programme and SDG 5 and 16.

2023 Narrative: UNDP played a crucial role in assisting the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic in improving the decision-making process, culminating in the adoption of Government Resolution #186 on April 5, 2023. This achievement brought about significant improvements, including streamlined procedures and the resolution of regulatory conflicts, thereby fostering a more efficient decision-making process.  With the technical support of UNDP, the Jogorku Kenesh (Parliament) has successfully endorsed its development strategy for the period 2023-2027. This strategic framework serves as a comprehensive guide for the new parliamentary convocation, delineating key objectives and approaches to enhance the effectiveness of legislative, representation, and oversight functions. The strategy is intricately designed to align with and promote Agenda 2023, showcasing a steadfast commitment to advancing national goals and priorities through well-informed and strategic parliamentary action. UNDP has been actively providing continuous technical support to the 30-member Parliamentary SDG Working Group. This support involves conducting workshops and training sessions covering various aspects such as SDG oversight, law implementation, budget control, and assessment tools. The outcome has been an enhanced understanding and crucial political support among parliamentary members for sustainable development initiatives.
2024 Narrative: UNDP facilitated the public-private partnership mechanisms in Osh and Issyk-Kul provinces by establishing Regional Investment Councils (RIC). The RICs cover a wide range of social cohesion related topics such building trusted relations, investments, regional development, youth and women entrepreneurship.

2022 Narrative: UNDP- A comprehensive analysis of the current situation regarding the digitalization of municipalities has been conducted earlier this year - providing a clear overview on the e-readiness of the municipalities in North Macedonia to achieve digital transformation. In addition to the analysis, a Methodology for digital transformation and a National Model of e-Municipality have also been developed - outlining the path for municipalities towards more integrated, systematized and sustainable e-service delivery. 2023 Narrative: 1) In partnership with UNICON.UZ, the ITU Guidelines on Online Safety for policy-makers, industry, parents and educators were localized (translated into Uzbek) and are being now actively disseminated to the target audience. State authorities are committed to use these Guidelines to formulate national policies and strategies that align with contemporary global Internet safety trends. In parallel, industry organizations will have the capacity to leverage the Guidelines to establish safer and more secure services tailored for children. Simultaneously, parents and educators will gain valuable insights to assist them in recognizing potential threats and risks children might encounter online. This guidance will empower them to preempt and effectively address these challenges in a timely manner.2) In partnership with IT-Park Uzbekistan, the course materials ‘Information Security in Digital Education Space’, developed jointly by the ITU Regional Office for CIS and the UNESCO Institute for Information Technologies in Education, were successfully adapted to the national context and translated into Uzbek. An online course on information security (available at cop-itpark.uz) is specifically designed to provide training for teachers and individuals who engage with children in their professional roles, and it is offered free of charge. Moreover, online course has built-in accessibility features, that allow users with disabilities to successfully complete it. It consists of several modules covering the following topics: information security issues, basic legislation in the field of information technology and information protection, the relationship between the use of digital devices and children's mental health, organizing children's information security behavior in the digital space, cyber hygiene and cyber security for students, computer viruses and analysis of software products aimed at ensuring children's information security in the digital educational space. Upon successful completion of the course, each participant receives a certificate that attests to their accomplished training and signifies their capability to apply the acquired knowledge in their everyday undertakings.3) 305 teachers (275 men and 30 women) from 14 regions of Uzbekistan, affiliated with IT Parks and IT-Academies, were trained on information security during a series of offline trainings. The trained instructors will apply their newfound knowledge over the next six months while teaching IT courses, thereby imparting the fundamentals of online child protection to their students on a consistent basis.4) ITU provided expert assistance to Uzbekistan on addressing challenges related to broadband Internet connectivity at schools, network resiliency and monitoring quality of service. The following national studies are carried out by ITU experts in this area: (a) study on the actual use and quality of Internet connectivity in schools; (b) study on the resilience of LAN infrastructure in schools. In 2023, a methodology for each study was developed and initial data was collected.5) In February and September 2023, 7 representatives of IT Park Uzbekistan took part in online training 'ITU tools for connecting schools to the Internet' (participants gained knowledge and practical skills about the most promising technologies for school connectivity, ITU tools to be used to estimate capital and operating costs in all sections of the telecommunications network (incl. school LAN), mapping and analysing broadband network infrastructure) and ITU regional event 'Broadband Week: connecting schools - expanding the opportunities of education of tomorrow!'  held in Kostanay, Kazakhstan (participants discussed policy and regulatory aspects of school connectivity and gained knowledge and practical skills on technological and economic aspects of broadband school connectivity).

Uzbekistan was selected by the Learning Innovation Hub as a Global Learning Pioneer Country, accelerating digital learning development supported by universal school connectivity through the GIGA Initiative. 2024 Narrative: UNICEF provided technical support to the Republican Scientific and Methodological Center for the Development of Education of the Republic of Uzbekistan (CED) in the development of the Requirements of Education Standards which are enabling competency-based education reform with focus on digital learning, climate resilience, socio-emotional learning for gender transformative and inclusive education. The requirements were reviewed and endorsed within the framework of the Local Education Group (LEG) and approved by the Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan No. 157 dated March 27, 2024 “On measures to improve the development and implementation of state educational standards and state educational requirements”. The Resolution has also established an action plan, mandating the CED to collaborate with the MOPSE towards the development of an overarching Strategy to ensure the integrity and continuity of educational programs in the systems of preschool, general secondary, and vocational education. Currently UNICEF is providing technical support to CED through extensive capacity building interventions to design overall methodology for preschool and school curriculum development with a focus on cross-cutting skills and competencies and inter/intra subject connectivity. Cross-cutting skills and competencies will include 21st century skills with a focus on gender responsive curriculum, socio-emotional learning, formation of life skills, along with introduction of new climate resilience and green competencies. This new framework for curriculum development is expected to improve quality of learning for 9.5 million students (2 million in preschools and 6.5 million in schools).

By 2025, Government and other educational stakeholders have increased capacity to provide access to equitable, inclusive, safe and quality education at all levels and promote lifelong learning in an integrated manner, including quality professional development system and decent work environment for education sector employees
2021 Narrative: Mapping School Internet Connectivity: Under the GIGA initiative, UNICEF supported MOPE to map the ICT infrastructure and quality of internet connectivity in 10,000+ schools in Uzbekistan, which stimulated the GOU to connect 90% or more schools to internet (compared to just 7% schools in 2018).  Under the GIGA programme, 7000+ schools are also equipped for real-time monitoring of internet connectivity, thus enabling MOPE to track the quality of school internet connectivity more frequently; and this is being integrated into school EMIS to enhance transparency and accountability of school-related services. Re-imagine Education: UNICEF supported MOPE in modernizing digital learning platform www.maktab.uz to meet the contextual learning needs of children in remote areas, girls, and children with special needs. More than 1000 courses from global resources on foundational, transferrable, and digital skills were curated and translated into Uzbek. Specific initiatives were launched to support girls in STEM, social innovation, and entrepreneurship skills.  Teachers’ online training under “Re-imagine Education”: UNICEF supported development of Teachers’ Professional Development platform which is managed by State In-service Teachers’ Training Instituted named after Avloni. By December 2021, more than 112000 teachers (almost 90 percent of primary school teachers) have been enrolled for undertaking training on new curricula implementation, which were developed and digitalized with UNICEF’s support and placed on the platform. More than 35000 received certificates of successful completion.
2022 Narrative: Within the framework of GIGA Initiative, the real-time mapping of school connectivity has been upgraded using an open-source platform expected to increase efficiency of national contract with internet provider. An innovative business model was developed to prototype extending connectivity to surrounding school communities, the first pilot in Fergana region is enabling access of high-speed internet to 2,000 students and 4,000 households to support learning of children and youth. High-level ownership of GIGA was also ensured with MoU signing with MoPE and Ministry for Development of Information Technologies and Communications.
2023 Narrative: Expanding access to school-based internet connectivity: Pioneering a public-private partnership model, two schools became connectivity hubs with UNICEF support, benefiting over 1000 households and 3000 children in neighboring communities. A private Internet provider and national agency under the Ministry of Digital Technologies signed a profit-sharing agreement, with 50 per cent of profits to be allocated for education and digitalisation purposes, with the expectation that each dollar invested in private sector will yield three additional dollars for public services.  Digital Learning Initiatives: UNICEF launched a pilot of the Eduten digital solution for personalized and gamified learning, including alignment of the platform with the local curriculum, training of 30 teachers to integrate the platform into regular math classes and 30 principals to foster a supportive environment. A total of 259  boys and 265 – girls, 5th-grade students benefited from this pilot initiative as part of a broader strategy to introduce innovative digital solutions for learning in the collaboration with UNICEF Learning Innovation Hub based in Helsinki

2023 Narrative: More than 30 Media institutions, civil society organizations have conducted awareness raising initiatives on freedom of expression and the right to information (commemorations of World Press Freedom Day (WPFD); International Day to End Impunity for Crimes Against Journalists (IDEI); International Day for Universal Access to Information (IDUAI). 30 Media institutions and civil society organizations are applying UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity with particular attention to the safety of women journalists. 2022 Narrative: With FAO support, the Armenian Government is aware how to setting up a sustainable Vineyard Register System with the staff of the Ministry of Economy having the capacity to operate the system.
2023 Narrative: FAO accentuated its assistance for bringing in the digital technologies in support of agricultural value chains and rural communities’ development in Armenia (TCP/ARM/3903). FAO provides technical support to the Government for setting up and deploying a sustainable vineyard registry system (VRS) by developing capacities for the effective use of the VRS, development of a mobile application to enhance farmers’ access to digital services. The ToR for VRS is currently ready in the draft version. It was submitted to the Ministry of Economy for approval and commenting. Additionally, FAO has proposed a meeting with all stakeholders on the ToR to facilitate the acceptance process. Finally, getting closer to the bidding FAO is expecting from Ministry of Economy information on the potential funding sources (government budget, other donors) for the development of VRS.
2024 Narrative: FAO has actively supported the Government of Armenia in integrating digital technologies into agricultural value chains and rural development by establishing the Vineyard Registry System (VRS). This system aims to improve vineyard management, support informed policymaking, and ensure quality assurance in winemaking. Through technical expertise and capacity-building efforts, FAO has facilitated the effective utilization of the VRS. The VRS Terms of Reference (ToR), developed by FAO, were revised to include scalability and multi-functionality based on feedback from the Ministry of Economy, external experts, and the Digitalization Council of Armenia. This collaborative effort ensured that the system could expand to other agricultural value chains. The Ministry launched the state procurement process based on FAO-prepared documentation, though delays in the procurement process have highlighted the need to adjust the project timelines to account for such challenges. FAO remains engaged in providing technical support, collaborating with vendors, building capacities, and amending policy frameworks to ensure successful project implementation. To accommodate the complexities of government procurement and ensure thorough development, the project timeline has been extended to the end of 2025. These efforts reflect FAO's dedication to promoting digital innovation and sustainable agricultural practices in Armenia.FAO was supporting the Ministry of Economy in developing the Law on Agriculture since 2021, working closely with the Deputy Minister to create the draft. After the initial submission of the full draft Agriculture Law package, FAO engaged in extensive revisions based on feedback from the Ministry of Economy (MoE) and other government agencies. A revised draft, along with responses to comments, was sent back to the MoE for further consideration. Additionally, partners such as the Austrian Development Agency, World Bank, and others expressed interest in collaborating with FAO in the development of the Law on Agriculture. FAO continues to provide ongoing support to finalize the draft.To improve state support mechanisms in Armenia, FAO assisted the Ministry of Economy with a study on EU best practices, offering a set of recommendations on subsidy schemes and relevant policies. A report with these recommendations for subsidy programs was developed and shared with the Government for review.

2021 Narrative:
UN Women Moldova launched a comprehensive program to improve women financial literacy, focusing on underrepresented groups of women and girls to be delivered during April. The program helped girls and women and their families overcome negative effect of the pandemic by teaching them how to make better financial decisions in time of crises. The program produced an assessment report on barriers and women-specific needs in the field of financial education, based on which 60 women were  trained. It will also produce an online guide for self-education, and will help women support and learn from each other, by maintaining peer-to-peer networking

UN WOMEN provided on-line individual and group psychological counselling for women entrepreneurs who are likely to suffer from the impact of the pandemic outbreak in Moldova. Sessions are held during March and April, weekly and are public to all interested people.

40 individual sessions have been organized, with 27 participants, couple entrepreneurs needed more than one session;
20 group sessions, with 103 participants
10 live webinars, with 7148 visualizations

Summer camp on Financial Literacy for about  20 young girls of 15-18 years old were organised by building their personal financial management skills and abilities.

2022 Narrative: In June 2022, six of selected students taking the “SPACE59” courses on Fashion design and pattern-making presented their works at the “PIGMENTS” fashion show in Milan, Italy, organized by Istituto di Moda Burgo; Two new 5900BC collections were developed by the “SPACE59” Light Industry Training and Service Centre Staff, Students and the UNIDO project beneficiary companies; Two garment pattern-making specialists and one hat modelling specialist after passing two-week TOT in Milan, Italy in October 2022, started teaching with Burgo textbooks and methodology at the “SPACE 59” Training and Service Center, official representative of Istituto di Moda Burgo in Yerevan,  Within the framework of "New Professional Horizons" project launched by the UNDP Sustainable Communities, training courses were organised for vulnerable social groups allowing future light industry specialists to acquire relevant skills and competences tailored to the labor demands of Armenia.
2023 Narrative: •      In January, the third set of students displaced from Nagorno Karabakh finished their sewing courses at the SPACE 59 Training and Service Center. This program, titled "Professional Horizons", was launched by UNDP Sustainable Communities in collaboration with the UNIDO Light Industry Upgrading project in Armenia and the project-supported SPACE 59 Center.•     In March, a group comprised of 12 students from the Armenian State Pedagogical University named after Khachatur Abovian (ASPU) completed a 1,5-month internship at the “SPACE59” that included training courses on fashion design, pattern-making and stylistics.•     In May, an international expert from UNIDO conducted a five-day training on men's suit pattern-making and development for the trainers and students of SPACE 59.•     The same month also saw the finalization of the Spring/Summer 2023 and Fall/Winter 2023/2024 collections for photo shoots, with catalogs subsequently prepared and printed.•     Moreover, an international expert in product design and development delivered several training workshops in May on topics such as trend presentation, sustainable fashion, and mood board creation. These presentations were followed by hands-on mood board development exercises, as well as practical activities on sustainable fashion which involved re-purposing older collection pieces into new fashion items.•     The conception and development of a new collection also began in May, featuring contemporary womenswear and recycled pieces from previous collections in response to current global fashion trends. Sketches were drawn up and fabrics selected, with the team currently developing prototypes. •     In June, the "Fashion Show Pigments 2023" event in Milan, organized by the Istituto di Moda Burgo, showcased five outfits from five winners from SPACE59. The collection received high praise from the Burgo experts, participants, and audience of the show. Some of the sudents’ works were also covered by a well-known fashion magazine “Selin”. Armenian Public Television prepared a special broadcast on the students’ participation in “Fashion Show Pigments” in Milan. •     In September, an international expert in shoe design and modeling introduced a concept on the creation of a new collection under the umbrella brand “5900BC.•     September marked launching of a new course on hat design and modelling led by a national expert trained at Istituto di Moda Burgo.•     In October, an international expert in production planning and organization conducted a master class at SPACE 59 Training and Service Centre, as well as diagnostic and capacity building activities on 9 Armenian garment productions.•     In October, an international expert in pattern making and modelling delivered a two-week training on men’s trousers modeling, adapting men’s suit in accordance with a persn’s body structure, internationally accepted methods on men’s jacket and trousers size grading.•     In October, an international expert on garment development and design finalized the new Spring/Summer 2024 collection with the SPACE 59 students and national experts. The international expert also introduced the fashion trends for Fall/Winter 2024/2025 collection, which was followed by the sketching and conception of the new collection. •     In October, a national expert on production planning and organization started a one-month training course with a new group of trainees.In November, SPACE 59 organized sewing operators’ one-month training course for displaced people from Nagorno Karabakh to enable them to find jobs at local productions

2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNDP played a key role in advancing the country's digital transformation agenda, bringing forward digital components in supporting the delivery of public services to all. At the policy level, the 2023-2030 Digital Transformation Strategy, developed with UNDP support, entails a whole-of-society approach and reaffirms Moldova’s commitment to building a people-centered digital nation, fully harnessing the benefits of new technologies. To address the digital divide, UNDP in collaboration with Tekwill in Every School initiative established 5 additional digital labs across Moldova, enhancing education service provision and fostering digital learning in schools, and actively supported the integration of women and girls in science and technology, advocating for STEAM-based education. Collaborating closely with the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, and Ministry of Culture, UNDP facilitated access to digital literacy through social workers and librarians, ensuring inclusivity in public services. UNDP efforts to modernize public services extended to introducing advanced solutions (MobiSign, MWallet – both in clearance stage) as a backbone for the future digital identity of the citizen for a seamless digital experience. By the end of the heating period, 895,000 households, representing 75% of Moldova's population (including refugees), registered on the EVRF digital platform compensatii.gov.md. This on-bill compensation digital service, supported by UNDP, contributed to the reduction of energy poverty by 43%. UNDP facilitated the use of data for evidence-driven policy formulation and decision-making. The successful experience with on-bill compensation for energy vulnerability serves as a role model for social vulnerability indexes under the social protection reform announced by the Government, while the digital map on road accidents will inform the upcoming road safety strategy.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNDP played a significant role in advancing Moldova's digital transformation agenda, driving efforts to improve public service delivery and support critical structural reforms. UNDP served as the primary development partner to the MLSP in the transformative digitalization of social protection. A new integrated digital architecture and a coherent roadmap were designed to address fragmentation and inefficiencies in services and programs, laying the foundation for more accessible, effective, and inclusive delivery. UNDP also collaborated with the Ministry of Agriculture to secure approval for an institutional roadmap for the Integrated Administration and Control System (IACS) in Moldova. This roadmap is expected to modernize agricultural administration processes and ensure compliance with EU standards. In addition, UNDP partnered with the Ministry of Energy to draft the Digital Transformation Strategy for theEnergy Sector for 2025-2032, which will set a strategic vision for digital innovation and efficient energy management in the coming years. To support local governance, UNDP introduced the Voluntary Amalgamation Online Simulator, enabling LPAs to evaluate amalgamation compliance, identify administrative centers, and estimate financial incentives. This tool promotes transparency, accessibility, and evidence-based decision-making in the amalgamation process. UNDP also made significant strides in localizing Moldova’s e-governance agenda, enhancing access to and efficiency of public services at the municipal level. As part of these efforts, the "e-Cancelaria" electronic document management system was implemented in Cahul and Ungheni, offering 17 public services and processing over 8,700 requests, evenly utilized by businesses (51%) and residents (49%). These initiatives have improved public service provision, fostered a more accessible and efficient governmental framework, and demonstrated UNDP’s commitment to creating a sustainable and inclusive digital ecosystem for Moldova.

2023 Narrative: The establishment of an expert group tasked with advising the Ministry of Culture and formulating a comprehensive vision for digital transition. The group provided recommendations regarding the transition process and outline the necessary requirements for a successful digital transformation.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNESCO continued its support in establishing a dedicated team through contracting a national technical expert, working closely in cooperation with the MCSC and its IT department, in addition to an international expert, dedicated to guiding the ministry to in the area of digital heritage documentation. The international consultant drafted a report on best practices for in the area of digital heritage documentation, storage and accessibility, to ensure its proper integration and interoperability with international databases and to serve as an essential tool for recovery and reconstruction. The national IT expert, supported UNESCO in the procurement process of equipment to the Ministry, including servers and laptop, through technical expertise, advice and identification of needed equipment. As for the procurement component of this activity, UNESCO launched an ITB in 2023 for needed equipment provided by the MCSC, with a deadline to receive bids on 29 January 2024. Following the receipt of the bids, UNECO evaluated 10 bids (for lot 1 – Servers and lot 2- Laptops) submitted by 6 international and national companies. The Evaluation Team conducted assessment of 4 technical proposals through online meetings organized on 4 March 2024 and 18 March 2024 (after clarifications emails sent on 6 March providing them with a 1-week DL – to 13 March to complete the preliminary evaluation and technical evaluation). The evaluation Team selected 1 bidder, who met all criteria of the evaluation, including technical and financial evaluation. Following consultation with PRO/OPS, UNESCO submitted the winning bidder to the Contracts Committee on 18 April 2024, who approved the awarding of the bidder. Thus, UNESCO signed the contract with the winning bidder on 23 December 2024, following many discussions on the rules of procedures of the Government of Ukraine to procure the equipment under Humanitarian Aid Law.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework

Description: With the view to support the reconstruction of the museum, conduct an independent assessment of the damages to the Skovoroda Museum based on the previously submitted damage assessment reports by local authorities. The phase would also include the designing of plans, including floor plans, elevations and 3D renderings, and to elaborate a reconstruction plan for the Museum. In addition, UNESCO was requested to translate the Museum’s scientific and educational web portal “Hryhorii Savovych Skovoroda” from Ukrainian into English, with the objective of not only further disseminating this rich source of knowledge with a broader audience, but also to preserve and promote Ukraine’s scientific history and heritage, as well as to identify new avenues for scientific international cooperation and engagement between museums. The portal presents the comprehensive knowledge and heritage of the philosopher Hryhorii Savovych Skovoroda while promoting scientific research and education more broadly.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: National systems are able to effectively plan for and implement inclusive recovery
Output: Institutional capacity development
Sub-Output: Advancing Digital Integration: Enhancing Ukraine's State Register of Movable Properties through Museum Digitization
Description:
This project aims to build on previous successes and lessons learned from UNESCO's engagement since the escalation of the war in Ukraine. The primary objectives include:
1. Capacity Building: Enhancing the skills of identified museum institutions and professionals to transition their object inventories into the State Registry. This includes the provision of capacity building for identified museum professionals at the Lviv Culture Hub, established by UNESCO.
2. Mobile support team: Based on the capacity building activities, the creation of four mobile support teams to roll-out support to museum professionals across the country to digitize their inventory and document their objects.
3. Pilot Projects Implementation: Conducting a series of pilot projects to complete or develop selected inventories and to digitize individual data sets of movable cultural property, museum collections, historic archives, documents, and existing inventories (including intangible cultural heritage). The digitization process will address various scenarios:
a. Standardizing already digitized inventory cards/entries to provide centralized access to decentralized inventories.
b. Converting paper cards into digital data.
c. Undertaking full digitization where no pre-existing inventory records and collections exist.
The project not only aims to safeguard Ukraine's movable cultural properties during the ongoing war but also seeks to lay the groundwork for sustainable cultural heritage management. By digitizing and standardizing the inventory process, this initiative will enhance accessibility and interoperability with other governmental databases and align with international digital heritage standards.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Ukraine Ministry of Culture
SDG Targets: 11.4 Strengthen efforts to protect and safeguard the world's cultural and natural heritage.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights

2022 Narrative: Ministry of Education, Innovation Information Center has strengthened its potential in delivering digital education thanks to the capacity-building in e-book development and delivery of 100 open-educational-source interactive digital simulations (PhET simulations) that can be used to teach STEM subjects at secondary schools. 25 specialists from the national education system were trained in developing EPUB format accessible digital books. The simulations are currently under review by MoE and will be distributed after quality assurance and approval.

The exhibition allowed to exchange advanced experience, generate innovative knowledge, discuss mechanisms for introducing latest trends in economy and public administration.
2024 Narrative: With support of the Chief Digital Office (CDO), UNDP collaborated with the Ministry of Communications and Informatization to organize the 30th International ICT Forum TIBO-2024, which focused on artificial intelligence. The event, inaugurated by the Prime Minister of Belarus, drew an impressive 88,000 participants throughout the week, positioning itself as a pivotal platform for discussing AI's role in digital transformation. UNDP played a prominent role at the forum, advancing its principles of AI use for sustainable development and engaging with key stakeholders. At the high-level panel discussions at the Forum, UNDP introduced AI for SDGs to over 1,000 government officials, industry leaders, and academia. Additionally, UNDP and CDO built capacity of over 200 national experts on developing AI regulation fostering innovations. UNDP presented its “Data to Policy” initiative to more than 100 representatives from ministries and the private sector, highlighting the importance of emerging data for policymaking ahead of Belarus’ next programming cycle, including the National Sustainable Development Strategy 2040.

Sub-Output: 4.1.8 Digital platform for refugees WeHelp
Implementation partners: Belarusian Red Cross, United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.,10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: UNDP with UN agencies and national partners developed a digital platform WeHelp.by as a one-stop-shop solution for refugees to access services and opportunities available for them across Belarus. Volunteers and specialists also used WeHelp.by to support counselling and referral of refugees. In 2023, more than 5000 refugees and specialists used the platform.
2024 Narrative: The WeHelp platform, supported by UNDP, has served over 28,000 refugees and specialists as of November 2024.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2: Peace - Effective Institutions, Human Rights and Gender Equality
Outcome: Outcome 2.2: By 2025, state institutions at all levels effectively design and implement gender-sensitive, human rights and evidence-based public policies and provide quality services in an inclusive, transparent and accountable manner.
Output: Output 2.2.2: Strengthened capacities of government authorities and CSOs for effective, efficient, timely and inclusive provision of specialized social services with a focus on the most vulnerable groups, including the context of the Covid-19 pandemic
Sub-Output: Capacity Building for Innovation in Governance and Digitalisation of Public Services
Description: The Project aspires to develop the capacities of civil servants to innovate in governance matters and for providing digitalized public services through differentiated channels of delivery, as well as to promote innovative practices. Its overall aim is to contribute towards improving the quality of life of citizens in the seven participating countries from Central Asia (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan), and from the Caucasus (Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia). To address these objectives, the UNDP/ACSH and the Ministry of the Interior and Safety (MOIS) and the National Information Agency Society (NIA) of the Republic of Korea have initiated this project to adopt good practices in governance and in public service provision through digital channels. The expected result of this Project is enhanced knowledge of public officials in the participating countries on the concept and practice of innovation in government and on digitalisation processes in public service delivery, as well as enhance capacity of public officials in the participating countries to introduce innovative practices and provide public services through a multitude of digital channels.
Contributing partners: Government of the Republic of Korea
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.,17.4 Assist developing countries in attaining long-term debt sustainability through coordinated policies aimed at fostering debt financing, debt relief and debt restructuring, as appropriate, and address the external debt of highly indebted poor countries to reduce debt distress.
SDG Goals: 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Q1-Q2:
The first study to identify the digital transformation needs was conducted in seven countries of Central Asia and the Caucasus. This is the first survey, which has thoroughly examined the needs of countries in the region in implementing digital transformation. The study is based on survey data and interviews conducted in countries of the region since 2021 as part of a joint project between ACSH, UNDP and the Government of the Republic of Korea.
2023 Narrative: 340 government officials have enhanced their capacity and have gained knowledge and skills for identifying best-fit innovative approaches in governance and public service delivery through digital means. Government officials in the participating countries and beyond, involved in digitalisation of government operations and public service delivery through differentiated digital channels have access to two relevant and pertinent publications produced by the project: (i) Open data policies and practices; https://www.undp.org/kazakhstan/publications/open-government-data-policies-and-practices-select-country-cases; and (ii) Standard frameworks for digital transformation; https://www.undp.org/kazakhstan/publications/standards-frameworks-digital-transformation Overall, the project contributed to the advancement and acceleration of the digital transformation in seven countries of the Caucasus and Central Asia, through a triangular development arrangement involving the Republic of Korea and several international organisations.
