Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK FOR ARMENIA
Strategic priority: People’s well-being and capabilities
Outcome: People benefit from a universal, affordable, accessible and quality health system, while adopting healthy lifestyle practices
Output: 1.2 Armenia’s health system is strengthened to be more resilient and shock- responsive
Sub-Output: 1.2.9 National Immunization Program capacity is strengthened to better deliver the servicies through digitalization of the overall immunization system, scaled up cold chain, trained health workers, intersectoral engement including academia,  improved governance, risk communication and community engagement, national policies to be  evidence and science grounded.
Contributing partners: European Union, Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation
Implementation partners: World Health Organization
SDG Targets: 3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: In close collaboration with the local governmental bodies and health workers, educational institutions, professional medical associations, Armenian Red Cross Society nationwide campaign “Vaccination is Care: Reaching out to People 60+ in Marzes of Armenia” promoted ~17.000 people in 60+ age group to receive their eligible vaccine doses during April- September 2022; addressed misinformation and build trust with communities in Armenia, including with HWs treating older adults and chronic patients.  Elderly population at the community level highly benefited of a broad range of supplementary medical services (hemometer and glucometer and broad medical consultancies per diverse underlining medical via the outreach medical teams from the national level. 2000+ teachers and school nurses obtained relevant knowledge in Vaccine-Preventable Diseases and vaccines/vaccination aspects within a comprehensive and innovative approach based “Fostering Safe Schooling” campaign. A web article summing up the nationwide Safe Schooling campaign conducted together with the Armenian Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Science, Education, Culture and Sport. The story was published on WHO Euro Web and UN Armenia.  Data-driven decision-making was improved via created Data management e-tools and visualization dashboards for Adverse Events Following Immunization management through scaled up Digital COVID-19 vaccination platform. National counterparts enabled to update the COVID-19 National Deployment and Vaccination Plan on a continued basis per provision of respective technical support matching the ETAGE AND SAGE recommendations. - Safer vaccination and introduction of a broad range vaccines w/different characteristics was enabled in the country via newly obtained equipment.
2023 Narrative: The Government of Armenia has capacity to better deliver the services through digitalization of the overall immunization system (including interlinks with other health components to check the patient immunization status on every potential contact w/health system), scaled up cold chain, trained health workers (including school medical workers and biologists  healthy lifestyle specialists), intersectoral engagement including academia (key biomedical universities comprehensively revised the pre-and post-graduate educational curricula for the pre- and in-service education of biomedical professionals), improved governance, risk communication and community engagement, national policies to be evidence and science grounded.

Un Women support women local producers to develop and grow their businesses in Moldova and abroad, and help them navigate in a business environment affected by COVID-19. Based on the conclusions of the need assessment at least 10 capacity building events on various topics will be organised. 2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF continued to expand and strengthen partnerships with private business resulting in engagement of 38,250 children and adolescents including 1,000 children benefiting from simulation tests on cyberbullying and 20,000 who watched a movie on cyberbullying produced by mobile carrier MTS and online news and trade platform Onliner. Over 100 children participated in cybersafty event organized by the national bank Belarusbank. In partnership with the Belarusian Athletic Federation and MTS, UNICEF successfully hosted the Family Run at the Minsk Half Marathon. This event, supporting children with disabilities and promoting inclusion, attracted over 2,000 participants, and raised $7,000 for assistive technologies. A partnership with the online retailer 21vek.by resulted in a social media initiative promoting eco-friendly habits and reaching approximately 500,000 people (77.6% female; 11% children and young people).Expanded reengagement with Priorbank clients was achieved by introducing a Corporate Pathway to Pledge (CPTP) model to support the “Family for Every Child” programme. The inaugural CPTP campaign in November 2023 raised around $14,000 in less than a week, surpassing average monthly incomes by 130%.In Vitebsk oblast, collaboration with Priorbank was further strengthened. The “Family for Every Child Programme” raised 51,000 BYN for mobile resource rooms and assistive equipment. Events like the Slavyansky Bazaar were pivotal in promoting the programme, with Priorbank providing branded POS-terminals free of charge.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.1: By 2025, effective, inclusive and accountable institutions ensure equal access for all people living in Kazakhstan, especially most vulnerable, to quality and gender sensitive social services according to the principle of leaving no one behind
Output: Output 1.1.1: Improved capacity of authorities at national and sub-national level to provide effective social protection programmes and social services, including COVID-19 related services, with the focus on the most vulnerable groups.
Sub-Output: Acceleration of a Digital Social Services Delivery Model to address the needs of the most vulnerable in Kazakhstan
Description: UNDP developed an innovative Digital Family Card digital platform capable of collecting, integrating, and processing information on the most vulnerable groups in Kazakhstan to provide state social support to key groups. The platform creates a holistic, gender-sensitive and efficient system to provide social support for the most vulnerable groups in society in Kazakhstan, prevent families from falling into poverty and empower local decision makers by providing them with real-time data on population categories in urgent need of support. The new Digital Family Card platform enables local and state agencies to proactively deliver social assistance to those most in need by consolidating real-time data from state databases and ensure transparent access to information about the socioeconomic status of families in Kazakhstan.
Contributing partners: UN Women, United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan National Information Communication Holding Zerde
SDG Targets: 1.a Ensure significant mobilization of resources from a variety of sources, including through enhanced development cooperation, in order to provide adequate and predictable means for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, to implement programmes and policies to end poverty in all its dimensions.,1.b Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Q1-Q2 (UNDP):
Theoretical methodology of Family Social Card has been developed across social sectors (employment, social protection, health, education, agriculture).
Family Social Card initial pilot has been presented to UNDP with data visualization tools; further steps for improvement have been identified.

2023 Narrative: UNDP supported the Ministry of Environment in development of a database with the ecological information collected from all owners of the ecological information. Digital economic development model with different scenarios of GHG emissions in Belarus until 2050 that covers all economic sectors was developed. The digital database is a platform for the national Ministries to take decision on measures to be included into the regulatory documents and 5-year plans to best balance economic, environmental and climate benefits.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, increasingly benefit from equitable, gender-responsive and universally accessible social and child protection system and quality services, including labour market activation and capabilities
Output: 2.1 Social and child protection
Sub-Output: E-Social: Leveraging Digital Solutions to Enable Efficient Social Protection of the Vulnerable
Description:
UNDP has supported the Government of Montenegro in establishing the national Integrated Social Welfare Information System (e-Social IS), which has been in operation since January 2015. Being the backbone of the country's social protection system, e-Social is in charge of processing nearly all social protection entitlements. 

To provide timely and efficiently cash transfers and social services and to ensure that new legislative solutions are duly enforced, it is necessary to continuously invest in the e-Social IS. To that end, the project envisages key components, including the development of new and upgraded functionalities (including its e-services for citizens), IS refactoring, capacity-building support for IS administrators and end-users, as well as its maintenance to ensure medium-term sustainability. The project will also provide, until 31 December 2027, procurement of additional server capacities as well as regular hardware supply replacement and maintenance in 36 remote locations.
Implementation partners: Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare Montenegro
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Gender equality is an integral part of this project, as key project activities directly contribute to gender equality by ensuring equal access for both women and men to their social protection rights i.e. entitlements to cash transfers and social services. UNDP has been a dedicated supporter of social protection system reform in Montenegro, with the aim of providing social protection to the most vulnerable groups, including girls and women. This involves offering tailored services and access to them, including shelters and a domestic violence database. Additionally, SWIS (E-Social IS) has facilitated easy access to social transfers introduced exclusively for women, such as those for mothers with three or more children, as well as ensured equal access to universal cash transfers that are available to all groups. As part of other project activities, UNDP CO has supported policy development in this field, including gender analysis and the collection of gender-segregated data through SWIS BI (Business Intelligence) module.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Human rights enforcement are directly supported through this project. All project activities, particularly e-Socil, enable citizens to enjoy their social (protection) rights and entitlements. The recently conducted IS Users’ Satisfaction Survey in 2023 highlighted that SWIS turned Social Welfare Centres into one-stop-shop access to rights, it improved work quality, monitoring and audit. SWIS actively supports the rights of beneficiaries and their entitlements from the application to payment (over 200.000 payments/transactions monthly, in amount of over 200 mil euro), as well as the responsibilities of duty bearers, by facilitating smooth access to services, data exchange, and proceedings in various cases. Moreover, the system facilitates online communication and cooperation inside the sector and outside with nine other institutions regarding social protection and fosters communication among institutions within the social protection system, which is of utmost importance for providing rights fulfilment.
LNOB groups targeted: Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Women & Girls, Children , Internally Displaced Persons, Migrants, Minorities, Older Persons, Persons With Disabilities, Victims of grave human rights violations of (slavery, torture, trafficking, sexual exploitation and abuse...), Youth
2023 Narrative: In 2023, the focus has been put on the development of the technical specification for procurement of the medium-term E-Social applicative software (upgrading, re-factoring and maintenance)  and hardware, servers and network maintenance for social protection public institutions. Other key deliverables in 2023, include:-         Daily support to the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare in e-Social upgrading and maintenance;-         Processing of new-born allowance (900 and 1000 euro) through SWIS, including retroactive payment for 2022.; increase of personal disability allowance (25%) to all beneficiaries and implementation of new costs of all kinds of placement services;-         E-Social BI module upgrade for production of annual Administrative Procedures Reporting, in line with the national Economic Reform Programme sub-measure;-         E-Social BI module upgrade for production of official Unified Annual Social Welfare Centres Report;-         Introduction of e-Social in two new homes for elderly in Podgorica and in Nikšić;-         Analysis and inputs (adopted by the MLSW) for Travel Allowances for PwD and sustainable inputs for Social Protection Strategy-         Capacity building activities for Social protection professionals/Ministry line Directorate.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, the focus has been on the procurement of the E-Social applicative software (upgrading, refactoring, and long-term maintenance), as well as hardware, servers, and network maintenance for public social protection institutions. Other key deliverables for 2024 include: Daily support to the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare/Ministry of Social Welfare, Family Care, and Demography in upgrading and maintaining the E-Social Information System;Implementation of the Social Protection Law changes for new-born allowances (€1,500, €2,000, and €2,500, respectively) through the IS, and two regular annual adjustments to social benefit/cash transfer amounts;Introduction of the 'levels of support' determination - new functionality for beneficiary placement in the social protection institutions; the charge scale for placement has been implemented accordingly with the new support level scale and increase of the minimal pensions;Upgrade of IS for the Maternity and Paternal Leave Salary Reimbursement entitlements through the IS, including an upgrade of the National e-Portal for employers (G2B e-service);Support for the administrative reporting of 2023 Social Protection Sector data;Regular procurement of hardware, an antivirus solution, interactive equipment, etc., for social protection public institutions;Support for the development and finalisation of the National Social Protection Strategy, in particular the Digitalisation component,;Support to the Ministry in ISO 27001 implementation and standardisation process.Capacity-building activities for social protection professionals and the Ministry's line directorate. In 2024 alone, around €230 million is processed for social protection entitlements through the E-Social IS, for over 200,000 beneficiaries. Furthermore, E-Social has been selected by RESPA and SIGMA as one of the three most outstanding projects contributing to enhanced governance and innovation in the public sector in the Western Balkans region.

UNDP supported the Agency for Strategic Planning and Reforms in the development of the reform agenda – New Economic Policy.
UNDP, together with the Academy of Public Administration, conducted digital readiness trainings for female civil servants with coverage of 500 people and developed an online course for further coverage of up to 5,000 civil servants.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.4_Rights holders, in particular from vulnerable groups, are empowered to access and claim for quality public services
Sub-Output: (UNFPA) Supporting the implementation of Active and Healthy Ageing by empowering and building digital skills of the most vulnerable older women and men to access social services
Contributing partners: Government of Czech Republic, United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: Help Age International
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: UNFPA supported the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection to develop and approve the National Programme on Healthy and Active Ageing. A national campaign on increasing awareness about Healthy and Active ageing was conducted, including a TV spot and delivering visiblity products. More than 150 representatives of LPAs were trained on how to integrate ageing principle into the local strategies to ensure the older people's needs are considered by local authorities. A study visit was conducted to Czech Republic to share knowledge and experience on University of 3rd Age that was piloted for the first time by the Moldova State University.
2024 Narrative: UNFPA supported local universities to expand and pilot the University of 3rd Age. A total number of 250 older participated at life-long learning courses/University of 3rd Age implemented in Chisinau, Balti and Cahul. A large communication campaign was organized in order to increase awareness and integrate U3A in national legislation. In this context, the National Platform for Active Ageing and Digital inclusion was launched connecting development partners, donors, private sectors, civil society organizations etc. to support the Ministry of Labour in achieving the targets of the National Platform on Active and Healthy Ageing 2023-2027.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: National systems are able to effectively plan for and implement inclusive recovery
Output: Inclusive Economic Growth
Sub-Output: Support for the digitalization of information flows for data and document flow for grain exports from Ukraine by sea; conceptualize multimodal transport and trade emergency corridors for export and import of goods
Description: Build capacity for practical digitalization of information exchange of data and documents (a) to increase the efficiency of exports of grain by sea; (b) increase awareness and capacity in Ukraine to implement the new EU Electronic Freight Transport Information Regulation (eFTI); (c) conceptualize a digital corridor Odessa – Constanta and between Ukraine and Azerbaijan to substitute for disturbed operations via Ukrainian ports.
Agencies: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
Contributing partners: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
Implementation partners: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
SDG Targets: 8.2 Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value-added and labour-intensive sectors.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: The first version of the report was developed in time (10 January 2023) and will be further discussed, notably with input from the demandeur of this project: stakeholders in Ukraine. At the end, the report will be used for both the digitalization of data and document exchange for the exports of grain from Ukraine (via this ad hoc corridor) and for other goods.
